DIV1.P: A CURIOUS HERBAL, Containing FIVE HUNDRED CUTS, of the most useful Plants, which are now used in the Practice of PHYSICK.
Engraved on folio Copper Plates, after Drawings taken from, the LIFE.
By Elizabeth Blackwell, To which is added, a short Description of Plants; and their common Uses in PHYSICK.
LONDON: Printed for C. NOURSE opposle Catherine Street in the Strand 1782.
Dat Conitus Censorus ex Aedibus Collegu nostri Die primo Julu 1737.

DIV1.HEAD: To RICHARD MEAD M. D. PHYSICIAN in Ordinary to his MAJESTYN and Fellow of the ROYAL COLLEGE of PHYSICIANS of London and Fellow of the Royal Society.
DIV1.P: As the WORLD in indebted to the ENCOURAGERS of every Publick Good, if the following UNDERTAK∣ING should prove such, it is but justice to declare who have been the chief PROMOTERS of it, and as you was the first who advisd its PUBLICATION and it with your NAME give me Leave to tell the READERS how much they are in your for this WORK; and to acknowledge the Honour of your FRIENDSHIP.

CLOSER.SIGNED: I am Sir with your most humble servant

DIV1.HEAD: To ISAAC RAND Apothecary and Fellow of the Royal Society.
DIV1.P: Your READINESS to ASSIST and Instruct me in this UNDERTAKLNG (which otherways would have been very imperfect) is so visible to every JUDGE who must know that I had no SKILL in BOTANY that I am under a Necessity to declare THAT IT IS TO YOU I AM OBLIGED FOR EVERY COMPLEAT PART OF THIS WORK and therefore I hope you will accept of this small ACKNOWLEDGMENT which GRATITUDE obliges me to make.
I am with the greatest Respect and Esteem

CLOSER.SIGNED: Sir your much obliged humble Servant Elizabeth Blackwell

DIV1.HEAD: This UNDER TAKING was with the following Publick RECOMMENDATION by the Underwritten Gentlemen.
DIV1.P: We whose Names are , having seen a considerable Number of the DRAWINGS from which teh PLATES are to be Engraved, and likewise some of the COLOUR'D PLANTS, think it a Justice done the PUBLICK to declare our satisfaction with them, and our good Opinion of the Capacity of the Undertaker.

DIV1.HEAD: Les PERSONNES soussignées ont lien wulu faire aá l'AUTEUR de cee OUVRAGE Chonneur de lui donner leur APPROBATION de la maniere uiante.
DIV1.P: Nous soussignés, agant v un asseés grand nomlre des DESSIENS sur lesquels on doit graver les PLANCHES, de mime que quelques unes des PLANTES ENLUMINÉES, avons trouveé le si bien EXECUTÉ que nous avons cengu ne TDÉE avant ageuse de la capaciteé de ltuteur & nous avons tout lieu de croire que le PUBLIC recevra cet Ouvrage favorablement.

DIV1.HEAD: INTRODUCTION.
DIV1.P: The Undertaker being desirous to make this Work more useful to such as are not furnished with other Herbals, is resolved (for there Sake) to give a short Description of each Plant; the Place of Growth, and Time of Flowring with its common uses in Physick, chiefly extracted from, Ur joseph Millers Botanicum Officinale with his sonsent; and the ordinary Names of the Plant in different Languages.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 1. Dandelion or Pisa-bed. Dens Leonis.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Leaves of this Plant lie on ye ground: the Pedlikels or Pipes on which the Flowers grow are about six or eight Inches high; and the Flowers yellow. The Root grows about a Finger whick, and eight Inches long full of a while litter Milk.
2 It grows almost every where in Fallow Ground & flowers most Months in the year.
3. The Roots & Leaves are used as cooling aperve provoking Urines & strengthening ye stomach. and are much eat as a sallad in the spring.
4 Greek Latin, Dens Leoms, Taraxacum, spanish, Diente de Leon, Italian Dente di cane and Piseta allette French, Dens de Lyon or Pisse and German Paenldatt & Runnichstopss Dutsh Papencrigs

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 2. Red. Wild. or Corn Poppy. Papaver rubrum.

LIST.ITEM: 1 This Plant grows to lie 2 Foot high the Leaves are a Willow green, & the Flowers scarlet.
2 It grows in most Corn fields and flowers in Iune and Iuly.
3 The Flowers of this Poppy are cooling incline to sleep & much used in inflamatory Fevers, Officinal Preparations from it are ye ple Water ye Syrup ye Conserve of ye Flowers & ye Tincturs.
4 Greek Latin, Papaver rubrum erraticum rhoeas Spanish Amapollis or Papoulla. Itahan Papavero salvnticho French Pavot sauvage or consanons German Clapper Rosen or Corn Rosen Dutch Roden .

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 3. Hullem or Hig-Tapar. Verbascum or Tapsus Barbatus

LIST.ITEM: 1 It grows to be six Foot high the Leaves are a light Hullem green & the Flowers a pale Yellow
2 They grow on ighways and Commons and flower in Iuly.

3 The Leaves are used for coughs, Pains in ye Breast and collic Pains & outwardly in Fomentations and are thought a specific against the Piles Doscortdes recemmends a Decection of the Root as good for the Tooth ach.
4 Greek Latin Verbascum or Tapsus barbatus Spanish Gerdelog or Verlasco Italtan. Ta o barbasso French Boiullon, German Beys Bullteraut Dutch Wolle kuut.
1 This Plant a ails on ye ground the Leaves are yellow green ye the Flowers a pale Yellow
2 It is raised from ye Seed yeraly & flowers & bears Fruit for serveral onths in the Summer.
3 The Seed is used for the Stone, Strangury heat of and Phsies says the Fruit chears delaye Spts and remends the Leaves boiled with ine and med with for the Bite of a Dog.
4 Greek .

1. The lower Leaves lie flat upon the Ground; the Stalk grows about a Foot high, and the Flowers are white.
2. It grows among Rubbish Banks and Walls, and flowers all the Summer.

3. This Plant is esteemed cooling, restringent incrassating, & good in all sorts of Fluxes & spitting of Blood, bleeding at ye Nose; the too great Flux of ye Catamenia, violents Floodings, & bloody Urine.
4. Greek, Latin, Bursa Pastoris or Thlapsi fatuum Italian Bursa Pastoris, French Bourse a Pastour, or Bourse de Berger German Sectelcrat, Secfel, or Zeschellcraut, Dutch, Borse kens cruyt.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 6. Wild Tansie, or Silver-weed, Argentina or Potentilla.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Plant creeps upon the Ground, emiting Fibers from the Soints, by which it roots in the Earth and spreads; the Leaves are a light green covered as it were with a silvar Down, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It grows in moist barren Ground where Water has stood all the Winter & flowers commonly in May or Iune.

3. The Leaves are restringent and vulerary good to stop all kinds of Fluxes & preter, natural Evacuations; to dissolve coagulated Blood to help those who are bruisedly outardly it is used as a cosmetic to take off Freckled, him burn and Morphen and is good in restringent Gargarisms.
4. Greek, Latin, Argeiuria Potentilla Tanateturn agresste Italian Patentilla French. D qrgentine sausage or Tanesie sauingge Gensertch Grensich or Grensing Dutch, Silverrunt.
1 The Leaves are a Willow green and Flowers yellow the Salks grow about two Foot high.
2 It is planted in Gardens and flowers in Iune and Iuly.

3. The Leaves and Seed are used being esteemd alexipharmis good against all and perhilential Diseases, and all kind of Fevers it eases Dtsorders of the verves, Hemle cornrulsion and Histeric Fits, the collick Weakness of the Stornach and Bowels, it repells Poison and Cures the Bite of renemous Greatures and mad Dog It is an Ingredient in the Aqua Brion comp and the Agua Theriaidlis. The officinal Prepara∣tions are the simple Water Conserve of the Leaves, and an Oil by Decoction.
4 Greek Latin. Ruta & hortensis major Spanish Aruda Italian. Ruta Fretch Rut German, Rauten or Beincruit Dutch, Ruyte.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 8. Wild Rose or Briar Rose. Rosa Canina.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Leaves are a darker green than the Garden rose and the Flowers are some times white, but oftener a pale Red.

2 It grows in Hedges flowers in Iune & Iuly The are sit to ther the latter End of September on the Stalks of this Bush ye Bediouar grows which is a green hury Excressence, made by small Ichneumon Flies See Ray's Cataloaue the Plante their

3 The Flower of the Rose are thought more restruioent than ye Garden Some look upon them as a spesit for ye Cataments, The Pulp of strenathens ye Stornach cools the good fro cought of Blood The Seed is ye Stone and gravel The Bedeguar is and to have the same The Peparation is the censerva .
4 Greek French le Roer to Flower puraoe

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 9. Wood Sage. Salvia agrestris or Scorodoia.

LIST.ITEM: 1 This Plant grows to two Foot high its Leaves are greener and broader than the Garden Sage, the Flowers are yellow, with purple Stamina.
2. It grows in hedges and bushy Places and flowers in Iuly and August.
3. It is esteemed good for the Got Rheumatism Scuruy & dropsy; provoking Urine & the Merises; it is an excellent vulnerary Plant preventing Mortisications & Gangreens.
4. Greek Latin Scordium, Sabvia agrestris Scorodonia Spanish, Scordio Italian Scordio French Chamaraz German Basserbatenig or Knolblochscraut.
1 It is planted in Gardens; the Leaves are sometimes a hoary Green & sometimes a reddish Purple the Flowers are a blush Purple and grows about is Inches high.
2 It grows best in dry sharp Ground, and flowers in May and Iune.
3 The Leaves and Flowers are used as good for all Diseases of the Head and rres; they are also duree and good for Obstructions of Urine and much used all Sorts of Fers in Tea or Posset Drutk.
4 Greek Latin Salan and Sala hortensis major Spatsh Salin and Salit Inatlian Salvor French Sanlges German Sallen Dutch.
1 The Lilly grows about four Foot high the Flowers are white yellow Apes in the middle.
2. It is planted in Gardens and flowers in Iune and Iuly.

3 The Flowers and Roots are used chiefly in extrnas Applications they are so sming and anodine good to dissolve and ripen hard Tumours and Swelligns and to break Imposthuminons Mitthiolus recommends the Oil made of the Flowers as good for all Pains of ye & contracted Nerwes. The officinal Preparation oleum Liliorum
4 Greek Latin Lilium allum and Lilium allum flore erect spanish and Lirti blanceo Italian laanco French Ias German Zilaen and Gilgen Dutch Lelie.
1 The Nettle grows to be two Foot high the Leaves are of a lighter Green than the Roman Nettle the Flowers are a dull yellow.
2 The Nettle grows every where in o great Plenty and flowers for several Months in the Summer.

3 The Roots Leaves and Seed are used as cooling and restringens the Jutch is thought good for all kinds of inward Bleedings Haemorchagtes and Fluxes Tent dipt in it stops the Bleeding of the Nose or Wounds. The Root is esteemed ete and a Specasic for the Jauride. The Seed is recmmended for Coughs of Breath and obstructions of the Lungs.
4 Greek Latin, Ur ureris and urens maxima Spanish Italiarl Crt French Orne German Belschoder Romusch Nessel Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 13. Iasmine, or Iessamine. Iasminim or Iasminum album.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Shrub shoots forth long slender green Twigs which would lie on ye Ground if they were not supported; the Flowers of the common Iasmine are white.
2. It is planted with us in Gardens and flowers for several Months in the Summer.

3. The Flowers are the only Part used Schroder commends them as good to warm & relax the Womb to heal ar Schirrthi therein and to facilitate the Birth: and also for a Cough and Difficulty of breathing. The Oil made by Infusion of the Flowers is used in Perfumes Matthiolus thinks that the ointment made of iasmine by the Ancients was not that iasmine which we have now.
4. Greek, Latin, Iasminum of Issminum album or Gelsiminum Italian, Gelsimino French Iasmin German, Beielrebe Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 14. Narrow-leaved Plantain or Ribwort. Plantago angustifolia or Luinquenervia.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to eight or nine Inches high; the Leaves have five Nerves which run quite thr them from the Root; the Flowers are of a light Umber colour with white Apices.
2. It grows in Fields and Meadons and flowers mostly in May and Iune, altho you may find some of it in Flower most Months of the Summer.

3. It is cold dry and binding: good in all kind of Fluxes and Haemorrhages as spitting or voumitting of Blood, bleading at the Nose the Excess of the Catamenia or Lochia. It stops ye unvoluntury making of Urine eases its Heat & Sharpness & the Gonorrhes & stops the beeding of Wounds. The Offical Preparation is the simple distilled Water.
4. Greek, . Latin Plantago anqusafolia & Luinque∣nervia Iailian Piantagine loriga or Lanciola French Plantain German Spigiger Wegrich Dutch.

1. This Plant grows to be two Foot high; the Leaves when held up against the Light appear full of small Holes; the Flowers are bright yellow, with a great Niunber of Apises & Stamina, which being bruised between ye Fingers emit a Hoody Juice
2. It grows in Hedges and among Bushes and flowers in Iune and Iuly.

3. St Johns's Wort is accounted aperative detersive diuretic alexipharmtc good in tertian and guartan Agues; destrous Worms, and is an excellent vulnerary Plant A Tincture of ye Flowers in Spirit of Wine is commended against Melancholy & Madness Outwardly it is of great Service in Bruises Contisions & Wounds, especially in the nervous Parts. The officinal Preparatios are, the simple and compound Oil.
4. Greek, . Latin, Hypericurn of Hypericum vulgare Spanish, Corajoncillo Italian, Hyperico and Perforata or Horbn di S Giovin French Millepetuis or Tyucheran German Sanct johartritcrat Dutch.
1. It grows to be three Foot high; the Leaves have a little Down upon them ye Flowers are red. spotted with white and grow all on one side of the Stalks.
2. Fox Glove grows in Hedges and Lanes; and flowers in Iune and Iuly.

3. This Plant is but rarely used inwardly being a strong Emetic working with ioderce upnd and downwards Parkon extolls a Decochion of is un Ale with Posipodus Roots as an approved Medicarie for ye Fallow Sickness. The late Doctor Hulse commeds ye ombrnest made of the Flowers and May Butter for sophulos Wcers which much dress∣ing them with the otntmentand put two or three Times a Week with proper oges The Preparation is the Unouetum digitalis.
4. Greek, Latin digitalis or Diotalis Purpurea Spanish. Italian. French La Digitale German. Dutch.

1. It grows to be three Foot highs the Stalks are hoary full of a white pith ye Leaves are a Willow green above, & a light hoary underneath the Flowers are yellow.
2. It grows in Lanes and wasto Places and flowers in Iuly and August.

3. The Leaves & Tops are used; they purge Melancholy Humours, provoke Urine, restore an Appetite that is lost by Drinking. They are good against the Disorders of ye Stomach vomitirg & Surseits; they strengthen the Viscera kill Worms, & are of service in Dropsies, Jaundice, tertian & quartan Agues. In all ye above cases it is infused in Water, Ale or Wine Alataplasm of the green Leaves beat up with Hogs Lard was commended to Mr Ray by Dr Hulse as a good external Remedy against ye sivellg of the Tonsils & Luinzy. See Rays Cat. Plantarum. Officinal Preparations are a simply Water; a greater and a Lesser compound Water; a simple and a compound Surup; an oil by infusion, and decoction; and oil by Distillation; and Extract; a fixt Salt.
4. Greek Latin, Misinthium vulgare or Ponticum Spanish Assentios or Alos Italian, Assenzo or issentiz French Aluyne or Absicnce German Wermut Dutch Alsem.
1. The Sailks grow about hteen Inches high and are somewhat hairy: the Flowrs are white and grow on the Tops of the Branches in flat Umbels.
2. Is grows in most Fields and flowers in Iune and Iuly.

3. The Leaves are esteemed cooling drying binding serviceable in all kinds of Haemorrhaes as spittino or vomiting Blood bleeding at the Nose Dusentery the too great Flux of the Mesises, violent flooding cooling and tempering its immoderate Sharpness; it is good in a Gonorrhea Stranguris Heat of urine; when applied out wardly it is of Service against Ruptures of Fresh ounds.
4 Greed Latin Uillefodiurrt teresre Flore albo Spanish Millhogas yerua Italian Hillesoglie French. Millefueille German. Garden Dutch Duysiud ad.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 19. The Garden Bean. Faba major, or major hortensis.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Garden Bean grows to be three or four Foot high; the Leaves are a pale Green, and the Flowers white, with two black Spots in them.
2. It is sown in Gardens, and flowrs in May and the Beans are ripe in Iune or Iuly.

3 The Water disrilled from ye Flowers is used by many as a Coswetic; & that firm the pods is accounted good for ye Wind & gripes in Children, Dioscorides says ye Meal made intoa cataplasm removes ue Swellings in Women Breasts which are oasioned by the Milk; he also recommends is mixt with Roses, Time & ye white of an Egg as good for purging all watery Rheums from ye Eyes; & med with Wine as good for ye Wb & blood shot of the Eyes. The Meal given inwardly is esteemed good for a bloodly Flux. The officual Preparations are the Agua Florum et Siliguarum Fabarum.
4 Greek Latin Faba major, or Fabn major hortensis Spanish Havas Italian, Faa French Fave German, Bonen Dutch Roomse or Bocre-Boonen.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 20. Meadow Trefoil or Clover Grass. Trifolium vulgare.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Leaves are a pale Green, and the Flowers purple spoued with white the Stalks grow to be hteen Inches high.
2. It grows in most Fields and Meadows and flowers in May or Iune.

3 The Leaves & Flowers are used as drytry bing good for all kind of Fluxes ye Stranoury & heat made into a Cataplasm with Hogs Lard they are reckmed good for tuss & Irslim matiow a Destion of Whole Plate tri Ploner stops Whites in Women.
4 Greek Latin Trsolum uvlgare Spanish. Itlian Thsoglio French. German Biesenilee Dutch, roode Klaateren.

Trifolium vulgare
1. This is the Eupatorutm of Dioscorides, Galen, & the ancient Greeks; it grows about two Foot high, having several winged hairy Leaves of a pale green Colour, and yellow Flowers.
2. It grows in Hedges, and the Borders of Fields; and flowers in Iune and Iuly.

3. Agrimony is esteemed cleansing and purifying for the Blood strengthring ye Liver, and good in all Diseases arising from the Weakness thereof as the Dropsy Jaundice &c. Matthiolus recommends it with white Wine as an excellent lure for the Strangury and bloody Water. Riverius extols ye Powder of ye dried Leaves for the Incontinence of Urine. It is likewise a vulnerary Plant&put in Wound-Drinks & outwardly used in Baths&Fomentations.
4. Greek, . Latin. Agrimonia, or Eupatorium Grecorum. Spanish, Agramonia. Italian, Agrimonia. French, Agreonoine German. Adermeng. Dutch. Agremonte.
1. Mallows grow to be three Foot high; the Stalks are somewhat hairy, & the Leaves are a yellowish Green, ye Flowers are bright reddish Purple stripd with a deep Purple.
2. It grows commonly by Way-sides, and flowers for most Months in the Summer.

3. This is one of the five emollient Herbs, being Loosening Cooling & Molifying A Decoction of the Leaves sweetned with Syrup of Violets, & drank now and then to the Quantity of a Quarter of a Pint keeps the Body soluble asswages choleris Humours allays the heat & sharpness of Urine, eases the Stone & Gravel and provokes Urine. A Catiplasm made of the Leaves eases the smart of the Place that is srung by Bees or Wasps Where Marsh Mallows are not to be had this may supply the Place.
4. Greek, . Latin Malva & Malva vulgaris, or agresuss Spanish, Malvas. Italian, Mallia or Malvas. French. Malve German, Pappel Dutch Kaasses cruyd.
1. It grows to be eighteen Inches high; the Leaves are a bright Gree & the Flowers white.
2 It is sown in Gardens yearly and flowers most Months in the Summer.

3. The Leaves are much used as a Sallad their warmth being good to help the coldness of others mixed with them. They are esteemed good for the Scurvy Dropsy Palsu and Lethargy A Cataplasm of the Leaves with Hog's Lard cures scald Heads the Seed helps the Scurvy and Dropsy and swelling of the Spleen; and opens obstruchons in the Femal sex, and prevents the falling off of the Hair.
4 Greek . Latin, Nasturtio Spanish, Nastrutio, and Malpica. Italian. Nastrutio and Agretto. French, Cresson de Jardini, and Nasitort. German Garten ess. Dutch. Thuyn-Kersse.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 24 Self Heal. Prunella or Brunella.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Plant grows to be a Foot high the Leaves are dark Green, and the Flowers Purple
2 It grows in Meadows and pasture grounds flowering all the latter Months of the Summer.
3 It is used for all Inflammation and Ulcer in the Tongue have and Threat either the Iu or a strong Detion as also for inward Bleeding & making of Bloody Water
4 Greek Latin Prunella or Prunella vulogaris Spanish Agramonia Italian. connsolida manner French for emour German Brunellen & Adeimenae Dutch Brunelle.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 25. Wood-Bind or Honey-Suckle. Caprifolium or Peryclemenum.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Shrub grows to the thickness of either or ten Inches on circumference shooting out long Slender Stalks which ovist about every thing they meet with the Leaves are a bluish green, and the Flowers a pale red: which are Succeeded by Berries of a deeper Red.
2. It grows in most Hedges, and flowers the greatest part of the Summer.

3. The Leaves are sometimes put into Gargarisms for sore Throats Some commend a De∣coction of them for a Cough and the Ptysick; and to open Obstructions of ye Livers & Spleen The Oil made by irysusion of ye Flowers is accounted healing & warming good for the Gramp & Convulsions of ye Nerves Matthiolus recommends the Leaves & their Iutes as good in the Ointments that are used for Wounds in the Head and Hlcers in the Lege.
4. Greek Latin Caprifolium & Peruclemenum Spanish Hadresilva Italian Vincibosco French Vincibosse German Beissblatt Dutch beutendlad & Mamments kruyd

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 26. Larks-Spur. Delphinium or Consolida regalis.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to be a yard high the Leaves are a dark Green and the Flowers com∣monly a fine blue; but sometimes a Purple.
2. It is Sown every year in Gardens and flowers most part of the Summer.

3. This is esteemed a vulnerary Plant of a healing Nature Matthiolus says it cures the Rheums and Inslammations of the Eyes; mixed with Honey & drank with sweet Wine it removes the sharpness of Urvie. It likewise closes up fresh wounds and heals Ulcers.
4 Greek Latin Delphinium or Consolida regalis Spanish. Italian Consolida reale French Ped Allouette German Rittersporea Dutch Riddersporen.
1 This Plant grows to be three Foot high; the Stalks are square the Leaves a light yellow Green and the Flowers white.
2. It grows only in Gardens here and flowers in Iuly and August.

3 This whole Her is used and esteemed cordtal cephalic good for Disorders of the Head and Terres chears the Heart cured us Palpitotion prevents Faintino Helanchely Hypochondrias and Husteris Disorders: resists Pubefaon and is of great server in malionant and contagtous Distempers outwardly applied it helps the Stinging of Bees and Wasps. The officinal Preparation is the Simple Water.
4 Greek Latin Melssa or Mebssophyllum Spanish Torongil or Hiewa iderra Itilian Uelsssa French Messse & Pomssrade German Mehssen Mutercraut Dutch Consily de greyn.

2 Hedags Mustard grows commonly by Haysides and on Ranks and flowers most part of the Summer.

3 This Plant is hot dry Tens & attenuates by its worming Luality it desolves thick and shmy fiumours langs helps a bough and thormess of Breath. It is much remon ended Hoarsness to rever love Rettus pratses Decanon of is Uine as a good remedy , The officanal Preparation the Surupis de Erison.

2. It grows wild in dry Banks and the Edges of Fields and Flowers in Iuly.

3. The Seed provokes an Appstite strengthers the Stomach and helps Digestion Diosoorides recommends the Iuice mixed with Water and Honey as good to gargle the Throat with and help Women ho are broubled with the Mother; a Cataplasm of Figs and the Juice is good for the Lethargy by laying it on the Head shaved till the place grows red & the samed Cataplasm laid on ye Hip eases the Sciatica. The Seed he recommends as good in Plaisters to sosten ye Scabs of the Head.
4 Greek Latin Sinapi alburn or alterum Spnish Mcstaxa blanco Italian Senape or Senauro salvatico French Seneve blanc German Gelder Senff Dutch Wit Hotard Zaat.
1. It grows about two Foot high the Leaves are a bright Green and the Flowers a plae yellow.
2. This Sow Thisele grown commonly on Banks and Honers in May and Iune.

3. The Leaves are of the same fature with whose of the Dandelyon being operative and diurette and good or the Grayed and steppage of Urine Matthiolus says the Roots and Leaves when young are much used in Italy in Sallads & recommends the Milk of the Stalk in Wine as good for an ; & the distempers of the Ear when botled with Oil Galen recommends ye Leaves to be chewd for an offensive Breath.
4. Greek Latin Sonchus asper Spantsh Serraya or Seralha Itatiar Sonche Cicerbita French Latteron German Biller Hasentol or Gausdisted Dutch Gonse distel.
1. This Plant grows to be a Foot high the Stalks and Leaves are somewhat hairy the Flowers are a shining bright yellow.
2. It grows in most Fields and flowers in May.

3. Grow foot is caustic and may be used to draw Blisters where cantharides cannot be had but they must notly on too long for fear of ulcerating the Part. The Bavarians extal the distilled Hater from the Leaves of the bulbous Sort, or the Leaves infused in Brandu as an excellent Remedy against the Plague.
4. Greet Latin Ramuriculus partensis Spantsh yervn belida italian Rrnoncolo or Pie Corbins French Grenotlltte or Bassinuz German anen Fuss Dutch S Anthonts Raapje.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 32. Water Mint. Mentha aquanca or Sisumlrium

LIST.ITEM: 1 It grows to be Inches high ye Stalks are hariy & ye Flowers a red Purple and ye Leaves a reddish Green.
2 It grows in Ditches and Watery places and flowers in Iune and Iuly.

3 This Mint is rather hotter than ye garden being carmuitatie expeling Wind out of the Stonoth helping ye collis it open Obons of ye Homl and procures the Cataritna. The yuce dropis into the Ears to good to ease their Eatn & help deasnes Dtopfoordes commends the Leaves boled Water as good to Reachina or Fos.
4 Greek Latin aquatica or Simbrurn Spanish Bteros or Aortis It a lian Sisembro Frethch. uerman Dutch Basse water

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 33. White-Archangel or Dead-Nettle Lamium alburn aor Urtica mortua

LIST.ITEM: 1. the Stalks grow to be a Foot high the Leavesa are dark Green and the Flowers White.
2. It grows by Hedges and flowers in April and May.

3. The Flowers are accounted a Specisic against the Fluor albus and are frequently made use of in a Conserve or Decortion for that purpose which is to be continued for some time, Some recommend this Plant as of Great use against the King's-Evil and all scrophislows SiveKings. The officinal Preparation is, the Conserve of the Flowers.
4. Greek, . Latin, Lamun alburn or Urtica mortua Spanish ortica muerts. Italcan Ortica fetida or Ortica morta French Ortis German Daubnessel Dutch Dood Nettlen.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 34. Woody Night-Shade or Bitter-Sweet Solanum lignofum, or Dulca marn

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Speces of Night Shade has many long ash-coloured Branches, that climb up upon any thing it grows near to; the Leaves are a deep Green, and the Flowers Purple.
2. It grows in most Hedges & watery Places and flowers in May and Iune.

3. The Leaves and Twigs are used and are commended by some against the Dropsy. Jaundice and King's-Evil Parkinson says it purges violently enough Prevotuis in his Medician Pauperum, commends as a kindly Evacuator of Bile Dioscorides commends the Berries as good to take Spots out of the Skin.
4. Greek, . Latin Solanum lignosurn & Dulca mara Spanish. Italian Vite salvatica French, Morele German Jelengerje lieber Dutch Groote winde.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 35 Broad leaved Plantain. Plantago lansolia or Septinervia.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks of this Plantain grow to be eight Inches high the Flowers are a whitish Colour.
2 It grows by Way-sides and Meadows, and flowers in May.

3 Platain is cold, dry and binding; usefull in all kinds of Fluxes and Haemorrhages as spiting & vomiting of Blood Heeding at the Nose, the Excess of the Catamenia or Lochia. It is likewise esteemed good for the involuntary making of Urine its Heat and Sharpness & Gonorrhea; it helps to stop ye bleeding of Wounds & consolidate their Lips. The officinal preparation is the Simpld distilled Water.
4. Greek, . Latin, Plantago latifolia or Septinervia Spanish lhantem or Tamehagem Italian, Piantagine or centinerbia French Plantain German, Megrich Dutch Weeg bree.
1 It grows to be 18 Inches high, the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Flowers Purple.
2 It grows frequently as a Weed in Gardens and is often found wold near Houses and upon Walls and flowers in Iune.

3 The Leaves are esteemed cordial comforting the Heart preventina Fatntness & Helancholy. The Tops are much used in Wine & ool Tankards. They are accounted Alextpharmis and good in masianant Fevers. The Flowers are one of the four rdial Flowers. The officinal Preparation is the Conserve of the Flowers. recommends the whole Plant distilled as good for ye Inflammations the Eues whether inwardly or outwardly applied. Latin Borrago or Bulurn Spanish Borrar Borrnes. Itaian Bortaqtne French Bortah But .

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 37. White Briony. Bryonia alba or Vitis alba.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks of this Briony climb up to a great Height in the Hedges; the Leaves much resemble those of a Vine; the Flowers are a whitish green Colour.
2. It grows in Lanes and hedges and flowers in May and Iune.

3. The Root is a strong Purger of serous watery Humoury, which it does both upwards and downwards & is esteemed good for ye Dropsy Gout Epilepsy Palsy & hysteric Disorders. Doctor Sydenham commends it very much in cases of Madness. The Faecula is much of the same Nature, but something Weaker. The officinal preparations are the Aqua Brioniae comp or the Hysteric Water and the Faecula Briorae.
4. Greek Latin, Bryonia alba or Vitis alba Spanish Neura or Anorca Icalian Brionia or Zucca salvatica French. Colubrine or Couluree German Stictrrk or Zeufelsturbss Dutch Wilde Wyngaarde.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 38. Great White Bindweed. Convolvulus major albus, or Smiax laevis.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It runs up to a great height when it has any thing to twist about the Leaves are a willow Green and the Flowers white.
2. This Plant grows in most Hedges and flowers all the latter end of the Summer.

3. The Root of the Great White Bindweed is somewhat cathartic Prevotius in his Medicina Pauperum reckons a gentle Evasuator of the Bile Camerarius Soubts whether this be the Smilax laevis of the Anctents.
4. Greek Latin Convolvnlus major albus or Smilax laevis Spanish, Correquela major Itahan Vilucchio maggtore French Liset or Campanetre German, Binden Dutch Groote Winde.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 39. Clivers or Goose Grass. Aparme.

LIST.ITEM: 1 This is a creeping Plant that grows annually from the Seed; the Stalks Leaves and Seed are rough and the Flowers are white.
2 It grows in most Hedges and flowers several Months in the Summer.

3. The whole Plant is used & is esteemed modorately cooling & drying good to sweetn ye Blood; It is also accounted vulnerary & of Servite in ye King Evil or which some give the Juice as a great Secret. It is likwise diuretic and helps the Stone and Gravel This is one of those Herbs which are commonly put into Spring Porridge as good for the Scurvy.
4 Greek Latin Aparine Spannish. Italian. Aparine or Speronella French, German. Klebcrnut. Dutch. Kleef-krugd.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 40. Wheat & Bearded Wheat Tritcum, & Triticum aristatum.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Wheat without Awns or Beards is that which grows most common in England some call the Bearded Wheat Dugdale Wheat.
2 It is sown comonly in Atutumn and reaped the Iulu or August following.

3 This Grain is reckond more nourshing than any other Grain for bread A Poultice made of it botled in Milk eases Pains and ripens Turnours is Imposthumations put of Bread tsted and dipd in Wine is good to stop Termitino be appbuno it to the Scomach. The Bran is used in Cataplasms and aplied hot in Bags for Pans in the Sides There was formerly kept in the Shops an Emplantrum de rusta Pants.
4 Greek Latin tlicum or Truicum arutatum Spamch Trige Italian Tormento French Fourment German Betssen Duth Tarran.

1. It grows to be two Foot high, the Salks are a purplish Brown, the Leaves a willow Green and the Flowers pale purple.
2. It grows in Highways, near Towns & Villages, flowring in Iuly.

3. The Whole Herb is usad being accounted cephalic, good against Disecues aris∣ing from Cold and phlegmatic Causes. Some coinmend it to open objcructions of the Liver and Spleen, help the Jauridice and Gout Outwardly it is estaemd vulnerary good for sore watery inflamed Eyes.
4. Greek Latin Verbenace sipinea Spanish Berbena Italian Verminacola French Vervaine masie German Fisencraut Dutch yerkruyd.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 42. Ox-Eye-Daisy, the Great Daisy. Bellis major.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow more than a Foot hight the Leaves are a deep grass Green & Flowers white with a yellow Thrum in the middle.
2. It grows in Pasture Grounds and flowers in Iune.

3. The Flowers of this Daisy are esteemd balsamic good for all disorders of the Breast and Lungs as loughs shortness of Breath Pleurisies, Consump∣tions and Wasting of the Flesh. They are frequently put into Ctozems and Decoctions for inward Bruises Wounds and Ruptures.
4. Greek Latin Bellis major Spanish, Buphthalmo Italian Occhio di Bue French Oiel de Beuf German Rinds ug Dutch Groote Maagdelieyen.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 43. Pimpernel or Male Pimpernel. Anagallis terrestris mas.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to be a Foot high the Leaves are a grass green and the Flowers scarlet.
2 It grows in Corn Feilds flowring in May and Iune.

3. This Plant is moderatly warm & dry with a little stipticity, and by some is account∣ed a good vulnerary. The Juice taken inwardly (by it self, or mixd with Corus Milk) is good in Conswnptions and Distempers of the Lungs. It is often put in Cordial Waters as alaxipharmic, & good against malignant Distempers. Some Writers of Note have recommended it in Cases of Lunacy and Dilerious Fevers Matthiolus commends ye Juice for ye Tooth ach; friussed up the Nostril on that Side where the Pain does not lie.
4. Greek Latin Anagallis mas Spanish Muruges Itnlian Anagallo French Mouron German Gauch heil Dutch Bastard Muur.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 44 Pansies or Hearts-Ease. Viola tricolor Jaccea Flos Trinitatis

LIST.ITEM: 1 It grows a Foot high the Leaves are a dark Green the Flowers spotted with a light Purple a deep Purple and yellow.
2 It grows Wild in the Borders of Fields and is also planted in Gardens flowring great Part of the Summer.
3 The Leaves are esteemed mucilaginous and vulnerary good to take off the Gripes in Children and prevent the Fits arising from them.
4 Greek Latin Jaccea Spanish yerua dt S Trinadados Italian jaea French Pensees German Genfarben Blumlm Dutch Penseen.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 45. Bramble or Blackberry Bush. Rubus or Rubus vulgaris.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Shrub has many long creeping Branches; there are commonly 5 Leaves on one Footstalk in the lower Parts, and three on the upper parts next ye Fruit, the Leaves are a deep Green the Flowers a pale Red, and sometimes White and the Fruit when ripe is of a black Colour.
2. It grows in most Hedges, & flowers in Iune & Iuly; the Fruit is ripe in September.

3. The Leaves are accounted restringent & are frequently prescribed i Gargarisms for fore Mouths & Throats the unripe Fruit is very binding and restringent use∣ful for all kinds of Fluxes & Bleeding for Thrushes & sore Mouths. The Juice of the ripe Fruit made into Syrup is esteemed good against the Heat of Urine.
4. Greek Latin Rubus, & Rubus vulgaris Spanish Carza Italian Rovo French Ronce German, Briamen Brumbeer and Grakbeer Dutch Braam bezein.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 46. Betony. Betonica, & Betonica silvestris or vulgaris.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to be eighteen Inches high; the leaves are a deep grass Green and the Flowers a red Purple.
2 Betony grows in Woods & Thickets & Hedge sides & flowers in May and Iune.

3 It is accounted a good cephalic hepatick & vulnerary Plant. The Anciente had it so much in esteem that Antonius Musa Physician to Augustus Caesar, wrote a whole Treatise on it. The Leaves dried & mixd with Tobacco are frequently smoaked for the Head ach Vertigo, & sore Eyes. Mixd with Wood Sage & Ground Pine it makes a good diet Drink for the Gout & Rheumatism. The fresh leaves bruised are good for green Wounds & to drans out Sptinters. The officinal preparations are the cnserve of the Flowers and the Emplastrum de Betonica.
4 Greek. Latin. Betonica. Spanish. Bretonia. Italian. Betoneca. French. Betoine. German. Betonien. Dutch. Betonie.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 47. Marum, or Syrian mastic Thyme. Marum Syriacum.

LIST.ITEM: 1 This Plant grows to be a Foot high, the Leaves are willow green & y• Flowers red.
2. It grows naturally in Candy and Syria; and is nursed up here in ye Gardens of the Curious, and flowers in Iuly.
3. Marum is accounted a good cephalic and nervine Plant, and is much used in cephalis Snuff, but is of little service else in Physick.
4 Greek Latin, Marum Syriacum, or Majorana and Cretica, or Marum Cretense. Spanish, Italian. Maro. French. German. Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 48 Brooklime. Anagalis aguatica or Becabunga.

LIST.ITEM: 1 It grows to be sixteen Inches high the Leaves are a grass Green and the Stalks a reddish Green and the Flowrs is fine Blue.
2 This Plant grows in Ralls & running Dutches it flowers in Iune & keeps 25 Leaves all ye Winter.

3 It is accounted a good deabstruent & annsorbn abounding with volatile Parts very good for ye Surry being an Ingredient of ye anliorbuns & that for that Dteruper it is like∣wise detersive & cleansina useful in of ye Kidneys by Gravel or slimy untoury at also for the Stone & Dropsy attlefus suit it is good to .
4 Greek Latin. aqca Spanish Italian French Betle German and B. bungem Dutch. & Beek pungen

1. It grows to be two Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green and the Flowers a hight yellowish Green.
2 It is sown yearly in Gardens and flowers according to the Months it is sowd in.

3. Spinage is more used for Food than Medicine, being a good boild Sallad and much eaten in the Spring as good to temper the Heat & Sharpness of the Humours, it is esteemed cooling, moistning, & diuretic rendring the Body soluble Serapius an Arab∣tan Physician says, that Spinage creates Wind; so that those who are troubled Chollic had better not eat it.
4. Greek Latin Spinachia or Lapathum hortense Spanish Spanache Italian Spinache French, Espinoches. German. Spinat. Dutch. Spinasie.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 50. Wild Teasel. Dipsacus silvestris or Labrum veneris.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Teasel grows to be four or five Foot high the Leaves are a light grass Green, and the Flowers purple.
2. It grows upon Banks in the borders of Fields and flowers in June and July.

3. The Roots are esteemed cleansing; the Antients commend a Decoction of them in Wine, boiled to a Consistence & kept in a brazen Vessel to be applied to ye Rhagades or Clasts of the Fundament and for a Fistula therein; and to take away Warts. The Water found in the hollow of the Leaves is commended as a Collyrium to cool Inflammations of the Eyes; and as a Cosmetic to render the Face fair.
4. Greek Latin Dipsacus sivestris or Labrum veneris Spanish Cardencha or Cardo pnteador Italian Cardo da Parws & Dissaco French, Cardon German dissil Dutch Grote Wildekaarden.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 51. Pilewort of small Celendine. Chelidonim minus

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow to be 6 or 8 Inches high the Leaves are dark Green and the Flowers a fine bright Yellow; the Root resembles the Piles in the Human Body.
2 It grows in Meadows & moist Pastures & by Hedges and flowers in March & April.

3 This Herb is accounted to be good for the Haemorrhoides or Piles to ease their Pain and Swelling & stop their bleeding the Roots being taken inwardly & an Ointment made of the Leaves & Roots applied outwardly. Some commend it for the Jaundice; & Scurvy especially in the Mouth to strengthen the Gums and preserve the Teeth.
4 Greek Latin Chelidonium minus. Spanish Scrofoliria menor Italian, Chehdorua minore French, Covilos de Prestres German, Pfaffenhodn Dutch Kelynspeen kruyd.
1 The Stalks grows to be eight or ten Inches high the Leaves are a grass Green & the Flowers a pale Yellow and the Roots a reddish Purple.
2 It grows in Thickets and under Hedges and flowers in March and April.
3 The Flowers are commended as good against Disorders arisina from phlegmatis umour. The Juice of the Root is used as an Errhine to purge the Head of touch slimy Phleom.
4 Greek. Latin. Primula Veris Spanish. Italian, Flore di Prima pera French Primevere German. Schlusselblumen Dutch. Greet Wildesleutel blm.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 53. Male Satyrion, or Male Fools-Stones. Satyri mas.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Orchis, which is the common Satyrion of the Shops, grows to be a Foot high: the Leaves are a bright Green opotted with Black, and the Flowers, which grow on a brownish Stalk are a Red Purple.
2. It grows in moist Meadows, and flowers in April and May.

3. The Roots are accounted a stimulus to Vernery stengthening the Genital Parts and helping Conception; and for these Purposes are a chief Ingredient in the Electuarum Diasatyum. Outwardly they are applied in form of a Catuplasm, and are esteemed good to dissolve hard Tumours and Swellings. The Officinal preparation is the Electuarium Diasatyrium. Dios corides says that the Roots of this Plant boiled and eat by men, makes them beget Boys; and the Roots of the Female satyrion eatby women makes them Conceive Girls.

4. Greek Theophrartus. Dioscorids Latin Satyrum mas or Iestrailltas mortorus, Spaish Coyon deperro. Italian Tascicolo di Cane French Coullon de Prestres. German, Schmal Knabaruout meanle, Dutch, Kulleyes kruyd.
1. This Plant grows six or seven Foot high, the Leaves are a light green and the Flowers a pale Red.
2. It grows in Gardens, and flowers in July and August.
3. Hollyhocks are much of the Nature of the common Mallows vid Plates22 but less mol∣lifying; they are mostly used in Gargles for the swelling fo the Tonsils and Relaxa∣tion of the Uvula.
4. Greek Camerarusi Latin Malva hortensis Spanish Malvas Icalian malva maggiore French Malves de Jardin German Ernrosen Dutch Stockroosen.
1. The Stalks of this Violet creep on the Ground; the Leaves are a dark Green and the Flower a blue Purple.
2 It grows wild in Hedges and cultivated likewise in Gardens and flowers in March.

3 The Flowers are one of the four Cordial Flowers; esteemed cocting mcistring and laxatour. good in Affections of the Breast and Lungs, helping Coughs and pleauretic Pains. The Syrup is given to Children to open and cool their Bodies. The Leaves are cooling and opening and frequently put into Glisters and Ointments aganinst Inflammations. The Seed is reckon'd good for the stone and Gravel. The Officinal Preparations the syruques Violarun.
4 Greek Disjcorides Latin Viola martia Spwish Jictetta Italian Vcla French Violette German Merken Btclen Dutch Diole.
1 If te saxyinge grows to be a foot hight the Leaves are a light Green and the Flowers White with yellow Apices.
2 It grows Headen and flowers in April and May.
3 This Plant takes the Same duretic and lithon good for the Stene and and scippages of Jine .

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 57. Bears-foot, or Black Hellebore. Helleboruster.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to be 8 Inches high; the Bottom Leaves are dark Green, and the upper light Green; the Flowers are a very light Green tinctured with Purple round the Edges.
2. It grows on the Mountains of Strisserland, Austria, and Stiria; and is planted with us in Gardens and Flowers the latter end of December, whence it is called the Christmass Flower.

3. Beary-foot was esteemed by the Ancients good for Melancholy and Madness, to purge black Choler and Humours ariseing thence; they likewise gave it in Leprosies, Shingles, the Itch and the like cutuneous Affections. It is also commended for the Gout; and of late it has been very much made use of in stubborn obstructions of the Catamenia. The officinal Medicine is the Tinctura Ellebori.
4. Greek Dioscorides Latin, Elleborum nigrum or Helleborus∣ter Spanish, Verde Gambre nero or Elleboro Italian Blleboro nero French. Ellebore noire German, Christwurt Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 58. Doves-foot, or Crane's Bill. Geranium Columlinum, or Pes Colunliucs.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Species of Crane's Bill grows a foot high, the Leaves at the Bottom spread on the Ground and are a bright Green; the stalks are a Reddish Green and the Flowers a red Purple.
2. It grows on Banks and Flowers great Part of the Summer.

3. It is asteemed a vulnerary Plant, usefull in inward Wounds, Bruises and Hemonhagies and all Fluxes. It is much cry'd up for the Cure of Ruptures in Children given in Pouder. It also helps the stone and provokes Urine.
4. Greek Dioscorides, Latin, Geranium columbinum, Spanish, Pico de Cinguenha. Italian Geranio French, Bec de Cicongue. German, Belscher Storchschnabel, Dutch Duyvevoet.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 59. Perininckle Vinca pervinca, or Clematis Daphnoides.

LIST.ITEM: 1. Perwinckle grows a foot high, the Leaves are a bright shining Green, and the Flowers a Hew Purple, but sometimes white.
2. It grows in shady Banks & dry Ditches; & Flowers most Months in ye Summer.
3. It is accounted a good vulnerary Plant & is often use in Wound-Drinks for Bruises Contusions. inward Bleeding, Waiting & spitting of Blood; & ye Excess of Catamenia, & ye Fluow albus.
4. Greek Dioscorides Latin Vinca pervinca Spanish, Pervinguq, Italian Provenca French Lyserum German Singrun Dutch, Virocoorde.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 60. Wood-roof. Asperula odorata, or Aspergula.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Stalks grows to be a fot high ye Leaves are a deep grass Green & ye Flowers white.
2 It grows in Woods and Copses and Flowers in May.

3 Wood-roof in esteemed a good Hepatic and usefull against Inflammations of the Liver Obstructions of the Gall Bladder and Jaundue. The Germans put it into their Wine as we de Borrage & Burnet as a great Cordial and Comforter of the Spains. The Green Herb as applyedly ye Country Folks to hot Tumourt, Inflammations and fresh Cuts.
4 Greek Dtoscorides Latin Asperula oderatl Spanish Rinina Italian, Rellia salranci French Garence German Bldt Ret. Dutch

1. This Shrub grows 6 foot high; the Leaves are a dark Green, and the Flowers a yellow Green.
2. It grows in Woods and Thickets, and Flowers in March and April, and the Fruit is ripe in September.

3. The Leaves and Berries are used by some, as good to purge Bile, choleric and serous Humours; but they purge with great Violence both upwards and downwards. Some adventurous Persons give them in Dropsies.
4. Greek, . Latin, Laureola. Spanish. Italian. Laureola. French. Laureola. German. Cross Kellershalss. Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 63 Sanicle or Self-Heal. Sawicula or Diapewtia.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow to be a Foot high, the Leaves are a bright grass Green, and the Flowers white.
2. It grows in Woods and Flowers in May.

3. This is one of the Chief vulnerary Plants, being frequently put into Wound-Drinks, and craumatic Apozems: and is esteemed good for Ruptures, inward Bruises, spitting of Blood, or any Hamorrhagies; and Wounds both inward and outward.
4. Greek Latin. Sanicula or Diapentia. Spanish Italian. Cinquesoglia Maggiore. French, La Sanicle. German, Sanactel. Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 64 Bugle or Middle Confound. Bugula, or Consolida media.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalk on which the Flowers grow are 8 Inches high, the Leaves are a Reddish green, and the Flowers a bright Blue.
2. It grows in Woods and Hedges, and Flowers in May.
3. Bugle to a toted vulnerary Plant and used inwardly & outwardly for all kinds of Bruses, Wounds and Cons, as likwise for Spitting of Bld, and from any Part
4. Greek, Latin Buguda, or Consolida media Spanish Italian. Bugle German Gulden Gunsel Dutch

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 65. The Female Piony. Paonia faemina.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows 2 or 3 foot high, ye Leaves are a grass Green, & the Flowers a fine Crimson.
2. It is cultivated in Gardons, and Flowers in April and May.

3. This Plant generally Supplies the Place of ye Male Piony; and is accounted good for the Epilepsy, Apoplaxy, and all kinds of convulsions and nervous Affections, both in young & old. Some recommend it in histeric Cases, the Obscructions of ye Menses, and ye Retention of the Lochia. The Root and Seed are hung about Children's Neck to prevent Convulsions in breeding their Teeth.
4. Greek, , or . Latin, Paeonia Faemina. Spanish, Rosa Del Monte, or Rosa Albardeira. Italian Peonia. French, Pivoine, or Pynoine. German, Peonien. Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 66 The great Blew-Bottle. Cyānus major.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows 18 Inches high, the Leaves are a deep Green on the Inside, and a light Green on the Backside; the Flowers are a full blue.
2. It grows in Gardens and Flowers in Iune.

3. This is rockoned among the vulnerary Plants, the Juice being commended against Bruises and Contusions which come of Falls, though a Vein be broken, and the Party Spit Blood; as also to heal any Cut or green Wound:
4 Greek, . Latin, Cyānus Major. Spanish. Italian, Fior Campese, Fior Miso. & Battifuocero. French. German. Cornblum. Dutch. Groote Blommen.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 67. May-Weed, or Faetid Camomile. Cotūla faetida.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows about a foot high, the Leaves are a dark Green, and the Flowers white with a yellow Thrum in the middle.
2. It grows amongst the Corn, and on Bank, and waste Places, and Flowers for Several Months in the Summer.

3. Some Authours commend this Plant as good against Vapours and Hysteric Fts. Mr Ray says, It was sometimes used in Scrophulous Cases. Tournefort says, That about Paris they use it in Fomentations for Pains and Swellings of Haemorrhagies.
4. Greek . and . Latin Cotūla Faetida. & Chamaemelum Faetidum. Spanish, Manzanilla. Italian, Camamilla. French, Camenima or Camomille German, Camillen. Dutch, Stinkenda Camille.

2. It grows in Corn-fields in Essex, and Flowers in May.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 69. Garden Flower de-luce. Iris nostras hortensis.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to be 18 high; the Leaves are a light Green; & ye Flowers a bluish Purple.
2. It grows in Gardens, and Flowers in May.
3. The Juice of the Root is a strong Errhine; when snuff'd up the Nootrils, it purges ye Head and clears the Brain of thin serous phlegmatic Humors.
A strong Decoction of the Root given innardby is a strong Vomit, and accounted good for the Dropay, Jaundice and Ague.
This Vomit is very offensive to the stomach
4 Greek Ies Latin Iris nostras hortensis. Spanish, Lirio Cardeno Italian Giglio celeste. French, Flambe. German, Blanr gilgen Beilwart. Dutch, Lisch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 70. Lillies of the Valley. Lilium convallium.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to be 8 or 10 Inches high; the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Flowers white.
2. It grows in the Vallies, but chiefty in Gardens, and flowers in May and June.
3. Lillies of the Valley are of great service in all Disorders of the Head and Nevers, as Apoplexy, Epilepsy, Palsy, Convulsions, Vertigo
They are much used in Errhines and cephalic snuff.
A Large quantity of them are put in the Aqua Paeoniae C. and spirit. Lavendulae C. and the Aq. Antepileptica.
4. Greek Latin, Lilium convallium. Spanish Italian. Lilia convallio. French, Muguat. German, Reyenblumlin. Dutch Lelie∣van den Daalen.

They use it likewe for Uterine o cructions, and in Fevers of all sorts
The Leaves are used in the Aq. Antepleptica. Antiparaly tica. Ntae Composita.
Syrup Stoechados. Ung. Martiatum. Caspar Commelin.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 73. The White Rose. Rosa alba.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree grows taller than most other kinds of Roses, having fewer Prickles on ye Branches, and those pretty large; the Leaves are a dark Green, and the Flowers white.
2. It grows in Gardens, and flowers in June.
3. The Flowers are esteemed drying, binding and cooling.
The Water distilled from them is much used in Collyriums for sore inflam'd Eyes.
The Officinal Preparation is the Distilled Water.
4. Greek, . Latin, Rosa alba. Spanish, Rosas blancos. Italian, Rosa bianca. French, Roses. German, Rosen. Dutch, Witte Roos.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 74. White Hellbore. Ellborum or Veratrum album.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow to be 2, or 3 foot high; the Leaves are a bright Green; and the Flowers a dull Green, or a dark Purple.
2. It grows in the mountainous Parts of Swisserland, Austria and Stiria; with us it is planted in Gardens, and flowers in June.
3. The Roots are a strong Cathartic and purges with great Violence; for which reason it is but seldom given inwardly.
The Powder of the Roots cause violent sneesing, when snuffed up the Nostrils, and is rarely used without milder Ingredients.
This Plant, outwardly applyed, is of great service in all Distempers of the Skin, as — Tetters, Scabs, Itch. &c.
The Officinal Preparation is the Electuarium Helleboro.
4. Greek, . Latin, Elleborum album. Spanish, Yerde gambia blanc. Italian, Elleboro bianco. French. Vee, or Ellebore blanc. German, Wi Nigbwur Dutch Witt Niesnortel.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 75 White Dittany or Frainella. Dictamnus albus or Frainella.

LIST.ITEM: 1 It grows to be 2 foot high, the Leaves are a dark Green, and ye Flowers red sometimes white
2 It grows wild several Places of France & Germany; but planted here in Gardens. & flowers in July.
3 The Roots are esteem'd cordial and cephalic, good to resist Putrefaction and Poison; and useful in malignant and pestilential Distempers.
It is accounted good for to other Disorders of ye Head. Opening Obstructions of ye Womb. procuring ye Mayes. The Preparations are the Aq. Antepileptic. Theriacab Pu. Liberans. Emplscipaam. Paracels.
4. Greek, . Latin, Dictamnus albus, or Fraainella Spanish Dittamo blanco Italian, Dittmo bianco French Dymbasade German, Gmeinar Dyam. Dutch, Frainella.

3 It is weken'd among the vulnerary Plants. being of a drying to binding Nature, is particularly commended for ye swelling of ye Scrotum, by ye falling down of the Intestins into it

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 78. The Red Rose. Rosa Rubra.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Rose Buh is less than the white or Damask; the flowers have very few Prickles on the stalks; the Leaves are a grass Green and the Flowers a light Crimson.
2. It grows in Gardens and flowers in June and July.
3. The Red Rae is more binding and restringent than any of the Other species, are esteemed good in all kinds of Fluxes.
They Stengthen the Stomach prevent Vomiting. stop tickling Coughs by preventing the Dection of Rheum. and are of great Service in Consumptions. The Apices are also accounted cordial.

2 Pomgranates grow in spain & Italy and many other Countries, and flower in June and July;

3. The Balustia, off, are the large double Flowers of ye wild Pomgranate, which differs not in its manner of Growth from the other; These, as well as the single Flowers, and the Bark are very drying & rescringent, good for all sorts of Fluxes, Hemorrha¦gs, Bleedings, They strengthen the Gums, fasten loose Teeth, help the falling down of the Uula, and cancerous Ulcers in the Mouth and Throat.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 98. Costmary or Mecoast. Balsamita mas or Coss hortorum.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow to be more than a foot high, the Leaves are a yellow Green, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It is planted in Gardens and Flowers in July.

3. The Leaves are accounted good to strengthen the Stomach, — ease ye Head-Ach arising from the Disorders thereof — It expells Wind and prevents four Belchings outward by it is used in Fomentations to comfort and strengthen the Limbs.
4. Greek, Latin Costus hortorum Spanish. Italian Menta Greca French, Coch, German Buser Frarven. Munk. Dutch. Balsame
1. The Stalks grow to be 3 foot high, the Leaves are a pale Green. and sometimes purplish, and the Flowers a greenish yellow.
2. It grows in Gardens and Flowers in June and July.

3 The Leaves are frequently boiled & eaten like Coleworts, ruith Salt Meats & in Sallads, and are esteem'd cooling, and moisting, rendring the Body soluble, and good jor hot biliose Constitutions They are used with other emolent Herbs in cooling Glisters.
4 Greek Latin. Atriplex-alba hortensis palide virens spanish Armoles. Italian Atriplice French Arroches. German Molten. Dutch Melde.

This Herb is peculiarly appropriated to ye female Sex, being aperature deobstruent Disorders, good to promote the Menses, expell ye Afterbirth help hildbed appease ye Strangulations of ye Womb take of histe Fits. It is usually given in a Decoction-There is a Srup kept in ye Shops made with ye June of this Plant & Sugar

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 101 The Peach Tree Persica Malus

LIST.ITEM: 1 This Tree grows to no great Bigness here, the Leaves are a deep Green and the Flowers a fine Pink Colour.
2 It is planted in Gardens & flowers in March, the Fruit is ripe in August.

3 The Flowers are opening and purging and are chiefly given to Children to carry off thin serous Jiumors, and to kill Worms. The Fruit is cooling and moistning gratefull to the Palate; but apt to putrefy and cause Surfiets.

2 The Almond Tree is a Native of Spain and Barbary, it flowers early in ye Spring and the Fruit is ripe in August.

3 Sweet Almonds are accounted nourishing but if eaten too much hard of Digesting. The Oil of the Sweet is to take freely of it before they Expect their Delivery; and of great Service to purge Childre mixed with any opening Syrup. The Bitter are used as a Cosmetic being cleansing and beautisying. The Oil dropt into the Ears is good for Deasness, & is frequently put among Anodine Liniments. The officinal Preparations are the Expressed Oils.

2 It grows in Gardens, and flower great part of the Summer.

3 The Leaves and Flowers are accounted Cordial alexipharmic good in all kinds of Feavers, they promote sweat and are frequently used to drive out the small po and Measles. Some commend them fore the Jaundice, sore nflamed Eyes, and Warte.

3 The Flowers and Leaves are used and ceteenld cooling good for all kinds of flanations and hot Swellings the Shingles andother Eruptions as also for Burrs and Scalds. DIV2.HEAD: Plate 117 The great Burdock. Bardana major. Lappa major.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The stalks grow to be two Foot high, the Leaves are white & hoary underneth, and a deep grass Green above, and the Flowers are Purple.
2. It grows by Way-sides and flowers in Iune and Iuly.

3. The Roots are Judorific and alexipharmic, good in malignant Fevers, & are therefore used in the Aq. Theriacalis. — They are accounted good against the Gout and Pains in ye Liml. — The Leaves boild in Milk, and applied is a Cataplasm are by some used for the same Distemper; as also for Burns and Inflammanons, and are one of he Ingredients of the Unguent Populneum. — The Common People apply them often to ye Feet & Wrists in Fevers — The Seed porvderd and given in white Wine is good to provoke Urine, and help fits of the Stane.
4. Greek. . Latin Bardana. Personata or Lappa major. Spanish Bardans. Italian. Lappola maggiore. French Gloteron or Bardana. German. Gross Pletten-Dutch. Klitsen.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 118. Dead or spotted Arsmart. Persicaria maculata or maculosa.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to be two Foot high, the Leaves are a deep Green with a spot in ye middle in shape like a half Moon. and the Flowers are a pale Red.
2. It grows in moist Places by Ponds and Ditches and flowers in Iuly.
3. The Leaves are esteemd by some of a cooling Nature, good againt hot Tumors Inflammatiions, Impoothumes and green Wounds.
4. Greek, . Latin. Persicaria maculosa. Spanish Hierva axegutera Italian. Persicaria maggiore. French Cuage. German Schmerken Dutch Pertch —-kruyd.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 119. Sharp Arsmart or Water Pepper Hydropiper.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Plant grows to the same height as the former. the Leaves are lighter and want the spot in the dead Arsmart, and the Flowerse are a paler Red.
2. It grows in the same Places as the other, and flowers at the same time.

3. The great Mr Boyle. in the Book of the Usefulness of Experimental Phylosophy. recommends the distilld Water of this Plant as a good Remedy against the Stone. It is commended also as very cleaning and good for old sailorn Ulers.
4. Greek . Latin Hydropiper. and Persicarta maculata. Spanish Herva. manchas. Italian. Pepe aquatico and Persicarta. French. Curnge German. Basserpesser. Dutch. Persich-kruyd.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 120. Buckshorn or Snnnes Creses. Coronopus Ruellu.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The lower Leaves of this Plint he on the Ground. and are in shape and colour like the Garden cresses. the Flowers are White.
2. It grows by Way Sides and flowers great Part of the Summer.

3. In the West country this is much used as a Salllad. both ran and boiled. for its great usefulness in the Stone and Gravel and several Gardners about London culnvate it in their Gardens for this End. being a great diuretic
4. Greek. Latin. coronopus Ruellis recta or repens Ruellis Spanish Italian French. German. Dutch.

1. This Tree grows to the size of a Cherry Tree; the Leaves are a deep Green, the Flowers Yellow. and the Berries red.
2. It grows in Gardens. & flowerse in March & April; but ye Fruit is not ripe till August or September.
3. The Fruit is esteem'd cooling, drying and binding, Screngthening ye Scomach. stopping all kinds of Fluxes & Loosness; & is goodin Fevers. especially if attended with a Diarrhea.
The Officinal Preparation is the Rob de Cornis.
4. Greek, . Latin, Cornus, and Cornus hortensis mas. Spanish. Cornolas. Italian, Corolo. French. Cornier. German. Cornelbaum. Dutch. Cornoe.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 122. Garden Clary. Horminum hortense. Sclarea.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to be two Foot high: the Leaves are a dull Green on the Face. and hoary in the Backside; the Flowers are a light Blue.
2. It grows in Gardens, flowring in June and July.

3. Clary is estem'd warming & drying. — Infused in Wine it comforts a cold windy Stomach. Some commend it as a great strengthener of the Reins. helping the For Allus. & intyor ating a Cold relax'd Womb Matthiolus recommends ye Leaves infused in Vinegar. & a bale Honey as good for Boils. — the same Author says that the Women in Italy put a single seed into their Eyes when they are troubled with any Redness. humors. or Dunness; but M'Miller gaves this Vertue to the Wild Clary.
4. Greek. . Latin. Horminum hortense. and Sclarea. Spanish. Italian. Scarleggia. French. Orval. or Toute bonne. German. Scharlach. Dutch Scarlen.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 123. Garden Spurge. or Lathyris. Cataputia minor & Lathyris.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The stalks grow to be three or four Foot high, the Leaves are a ash Green and the Flowerse yellowish.
2. It grows in Gardens. and flowers for several Months in the Summer.

3. Some use this Plant to purge watery Humors. which it does with great Violence both up wards and downwards, and is seldome used for this but by Emperies. The Milk of the stalks destroy Warts by anointing them with it.
4. Greek. . Latin. Lathy. & Cataputia minor. Spanish Tartago. Italian. Cataputia minore. French. Espurge. German. Springeraut Dutch, Springs kruyd Spurge.

2. It grows in Marshey Grounds, particularly behind the Bishop of London's House at Fulham.

3. Matthiolus says this has the same Vertues as the Teasels. & ye Root of this boiled to the. Consistence of Beese Waxn Wine, and kept in a Brazen Veeel is good for a Fisla and Clefts in the Fundament — The Rain Water found in ye Hollew of the Leaves is common dd by some to cool Inflammations of ye Eyes, & to render the Face fair.
4. Greek Latin. Virga Pastorts Spanish. Italian Virga Pastore. French. Vinye de Pasteur German Dutch.

1. It seldome grows to be a Tree of any great Bigness in England; the Leaves are a grass Green. and the Fruit when ripe of a bronnitsh Green: it heareth no visible Flowers, which mates it believed they are hid in the Fruit.

2. Its Native soils are Turky, Spain and Portugal; and its time of Bearing is in Spring and Autumn: the Figs are cured by dipping them in scalding hot Lye. made of ye Ashes of the Cuttings of the Tree and afterwards they dry them carefully in the Sun.

3. Figs are esteem'd cooling and moistning, good for Coughs, shortness of Breath. and all Diseases of the Breast: as also the Swne and Gravel, — and the small Pox and Measels, which they drive out. — Outwardly they are dissolving and ripening, good for Smposthumations and Swellings and pestilential Bulves.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 126. The Mullerry Tree Morus. — mgra vulgaris.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This gron to be a tall Tree. the Leaves are a dark green. the Flowers yellowish. and the Berries when ripe a dark Purple.
2. It grons in Gardens. and the Fruit is ripe in August and September.

3. The Bark of the Root is thought to warm and dry. opening obseructions of the Liver and Spleen. and helping the Jaundice. — The unripe Fruit is binding and drying, good in all kinds of Fluxes, and Inflammations of the Mouth and Throat. — The ripe Fruit is cooling. good to allay the Heat of Burning Fevers. and create an appetite.
4. Greek . Latin. Morus. & Morus arlor. Spanish. Moras del Moral. Italian. Moro. French. Maurier. German. Miulleerbaum. Dutch Morbesien.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 127. The Male Cypress Tree. Cupressus mas.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This grows to be a tall Tree. but is not so much branch'd as the Female the Leaws a grass Green the Flowers a dirty yellow. & the Cones. which are rounder than ye .
2. It grows wild in Creet. the Flowers come forth the Beginning of Summer. and are ripe in Autumn.

3. The Cones are accounted drying and binding. good to stop spitting of Blood Dyarrheas. Dysenteries. immederate Flux of the Menses, involigntary Miction — They likewise prevent the Bleeding of the Gurns and fasten loose Teeth. — Cutwardly they are used in supe Fomentations and Cataplasms.
4. Greek. . Latin. Cupressus mas. Spanish Cipres. Italian. Cipress. French. Cypres German. Cipressen. Dutch. Cypresse Boom.

3. This Plant is esteemd heating and drying. good for Disorders and Suffocations of the Womb. ysters Fits. hastening the Birth. expelling the after birth, and pretering the Catamenta

2. It grows upon Banks and Way-sides, and flowers in May and Iune.

3. The Leaves are much ofthe Nature of Dandelyon. being apperative and dinretic. good for the Gravel and Stoppage of Urine. Some boil the Leaves in Posset-drink & give it in Fevers. The Young Shoots are often eat among Sallads as Lettice.

1. The Stalks grow to be two Foot high, the Leaves are a light yellowish Green, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It is sowen in Gardens, and flowers in Iuly, the Fruit being ripe in September.

3. Love-Apple outwardly applyed is esteemed cooling and moistning, good for Inflammations & Erysipelas; the Juice is commended in hot Defluctions of Rheum upon the Eyes. In Italy they eat them with Oil and Vinegar as we do Cucumbers.
4. Greek, . Latin, Pomum Amoris, Solanum pomiserum, Spanish Italian, Pomo d'Oro. French Pommes d'Amours German, Gold apffell. Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 134. Mastich Time or Herb Mastich. Marum Vulgare.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to be a Foot high, the Leaves are a deep Green, and the Flowers white.
2. It is planted in Gardens, and flowers in Iune and Iuly.

3. It is much of the Nature of Marjoram: Some commend it for the too great Flux of the Catamenia, a Drachm of the Powder being given in rough Wine Dioscorides commends a Decoction of the Leaves as good for the Dropsy, when it has not got too great a Head; and the Leaves mixt with Honey as good for removing the Blackness of any Bruise.
4. Greek, . Latin, Marum vulgare, Sampsitchus, Spanish, Majorana Italian, Majorana gentile, French, Marone gentile German, Megeran, Dutch Mastick ruykende Marum.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 135 Buckthorn. Rhamnus catharticus. Spina cervina.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Bush has Branches full of long stiff Thorns, the Leaves are a yellowish Green, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It grows in Woods & Hedges, flowers in Iune, and the Berries are ripe in September.

3. The Juice of the Berries purges serous watery Humourts, and is esteemed good for the Gout, Dropsy, Jaundice, Scurvy, Itch, and all manner of Eruphons in the Skin. The Officinal Preparation is the Surupus Spina ervina.
4. Greek Bav; Latin, Rhamnus catharlicus, Spina Cervin Spanish, Smlmnes Italian, spine Spine French Burguespin, eprum German Begdern, Dutch Rhynbesion.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 136 Black or Stinking Horehound. Marrubium Nigrum Ballote.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalk grow to be two Feet high, the Leaves are a dark Green, and the Flowers a blue Purple
2. It grows by hgh Ways and Hedges, flowring for several Months in the Summer
3. Dserides says the Leaves beaten with Sale and applued to the Wound the Bie of a Mad Dog, and the mixt with is good to cleaner Dtry Benle commends it as a singular Remedy .
4. Greek Latin Marrubium nigrum of Ballote Spanish Italian French Dutch,

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 137. Quinces. Cydonea, or Mala Cotonea Majora

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree seldom grows so big as the apple Tree, having usually a crooked Body with many weak Branches. The Leaves are like those of the apple Tree, but rounder and whitish underneath; the Blossomes are a whitish Purple, and the Fruit a yellow Green, covered with a Down.
2. It is commonly planted by Ponds and Moats, flowring in May, the Fruit being ripe in September and October.

3. The Fruit is accounted cordial and strengthning to the Smach, helping Degestion, and Stopping Vomiting & the Hiccpugh.—They are also esteemed good for all sorts of Fluxes. The Seed is balsamic and mollifying, tempering the Acrimony of Humors & serviceable against sore Mouths. Throats, and a Thrush; for which a Mucilage made of them is frequently prescribed. Outwardly it is applyed to heal sore chopd Nipples.
4. Greek, . Latin, Cydonea, or Cotonea majora, Spanish, Membrilhos. Italian, Mle Cotogne. French Pomes de Coing. German. Gross Quitten. Dutch. Quee-Boom.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 138. Harts Tongue. Langua Cervina, & Phyllitis.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Plant grows to be a Foot high, the Leaves are a fine grass Green, the Seed grows in broad oblique Lines on the Backside of the Leaves.
2. It grows in Shady Lanes and old Stone Buildings, being green all the Year.

3. It is much commended for Disorders of the Liver and Spleen, being good to Dis∣solve hard schirrhous Tumours in either.—It is usefull in the Rickets, Spitting of Blood and the Bloody Flux. Mr RAY recommends the Powder, or Conserve of ye green Leaves, for Histeric & Convulsive Fits, and the Palpitation of the Heart.
4. Greek, . Latin, Lingua Cervina. Spanish, Lingua cervina. Italian, Lingua cervina. French, Lang de Cerf. German, Hirschtungen. Dutch, Herts Tonge.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 139. Agnus Castus, or The Chaste Tree. Vitex. or Agnus Castus.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree grows about the Bigness of a small Cherry Tree the Leaves are a dark Green above and whitish underneath, the Flowers are a whitish Purple. & ye Seed a blackish Grey
2. It is Native of Italy, & is planted here in Gardens, flowring the latter End of Summer

3. The Leaves Flowers & Seed are esteemed warming and drying, helps the Hardness of the Liver & Spleen, expells Wind & brings down ye Catamenta Formerly ye Seed was much used to allay venercal eat. & preserve Chasty, but the Age has left that Medicine out of their Dispensatory as ūseless.
4. Greek . Latin, Ameriana Spanish. Gaigli casto Italian Agn cat French. Cast German Schasmullet Dutch. Kuys Boom

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 140 Privet or Prim Print Liqustrum

LIST.ITEM: 1. This is a low Shrub, the Leaves are a grass Green, the Flowers White & the Berries Black
2. It grows in Hedges and flowers in May & Iune ye Berries being ripe in September

3. The Leaves and Flowers are accounted cooling drying & restingena, good for Ulcers & Inflammations of ye Throat. Blooding of the Gums and Rela of the la Dioscorides commends the Flowers steepd in Vinegar as good for the Head Ach
4. Greek, . Latin. Ioustrum Spanish. Mfena or Hallena Italian. French Troesne or Trezillen German. Benholk oder Dutch Monthut keelkward

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 141. The Apple Tree. Malus sativa.

LIST.ITEM: 1. Among the great variety of Apples, those which are accounted best for Medi∣cinal Use are the Pearmain and Pippin. — The largest Pearmain is ye Here — fordshire. The Leaves are a dark grass Green above, and hoary underneath; and the Blossoms white tinctured with purple.
2. It is planted in Gardens and flowers in March.
3. Apples are accounted cordial, chearing the Spirits and driving away Melancholy. Of the Juice is made the Syrups & Pomis, which is an Ingredient in ye Conectio Alkermis
4. Greek, . Latin, Malus sativa. Spanish. Mansanas. Italian, Mele, or Pome. French. Pomes. German. Depsell. Dutch. Appelen.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 142. Devil's Bit, or smooth Succisa. Morsus Diaboli & Succsa.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow to be a Foot and a half high, the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Flowers a blue Purple.
2. It grows in Meadows and Pasture Grounds, and flowers ye latter end of Summer.

3. The Leaves are esteem'd alexipharmic, use full in malignant Fevers and Pesti¦lential Distempters. Outwardly as a Cataplasm they are good for Bruises and Contusions. The Herb Women sell the Leaves of this Plant instead of the common Seabious.
4. Greek. Latin, Succisa or Morsus Daboli. Spanish Italian, Morso d Diavo. French. German. Zeuffels Mbiss. Dutch. Duyvels Beed.
1. This is a low creeping Plant; the Leaves are a light Green, and the Flowers a bluish Purple.
2. It grows in Woods and Shady Places, flowring in Iune.
3. This is esteemed a vulnarary Plant, being used both inwardly & outwardly. Some account is good for Coughs and Consumptions, the Stone Stranguay, and pestilential Fevere.
4. Greek. Latin. Veronica mas. Spanish Italian. Veronica French. German. . Dutch.
1. The Stalks grow four or five Inches above Ground. The Leaves are a dark grass Green, and the Flowers purple with red Stamina, which is ye Saffron of the Shops.
2. The best Saffron grows in Es, Suffo and Cambridge shire, it flowers in September and October.

3. Saffron is esteemed a great Cordial, strengthening ye Heart & vital spirits, resisting Putresaction & usefull in all Kinds of malinans & contagious Distempers Fevers. Small Pox. & Measles. It opens obstructions of ye Liver & Spleen helps ye Jaundice brings down ye Catamenta expediates the Birth. & expells ye Secundines. It is also good in Diseases of ye Lungs as Asthmas, or Consumpuens Outwardly in Pulnes it tases Pains & ripens Impthuma now
4. Greek, . Latin. & Crocus Sati Spanish. Azaffran Italian. Zaffar an French. Zaffran German Saffron Dutch Saffraan

1. The Pomgranate Tree which bears Fruit produces a single Flower of the same Colour as the double; and the Tree it self differs very little from the other.
2. This Tree, as well as the other, grows in Spain, Italy, and the warm Countries.

3. The single Flowers are drying and restringent, good for Hemorrhagies & Bleedings both inward and outward. The Fruit is gratefull and strengthning to the Stomach, stops Looseness and the immoderate Flux of the Terms; and is usefull in hot bliose Fevers, and Gonorrheas.
4. Greek, . Latin. Granata. Spanish, Granadas. Italian, Melagrano, or Pomo granato. French, Pomes de Grenades or Mygrains: German, Granatopffelbaum. Dutch. Granat Boom.
1. It grows to be three Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green. & ye flowers a pale Red.
2. It is sown in the spring and flowers in Iuly and August.

3. The Green Leaves are used in Ointments and Oils, for Wounds, Ulcers, Inflammations. Tumours. Pales and the King's Evil. The dryed Leaves are a strong Emetic, & ought to be used with great Caution.—chew'd or smoak'd it evacuates Phlegm.—A Drop of are Disulled oil taken inwardly will kill a Cat. sometimes this Oil is dropt into a hollow Tooth to cure the Tooth Ach. The Dust destroys Fleas. Lice. & other Vermine.
4. Greek, . Latin. Petum. Hyoscy amus Peruvianus. Spanish, Petun and Tabaco. Italian. French. Harbn de la Roine Mere. German India. nisch Bundecraut. Dutch. Taback.
1. The Stalks grow to be six or eight Inches high, the Leaves are a grass Green potted with white above, & purplish underneath. & the Flowers a pale Red.
2. It is planted here in Gardens, flowring in September and October; its Native Places being the Alps, Austria, & Styria.

3. The Root is very forcing, and usefull to bring away the Birth and Secundines, and provoke the Menses. Some commend the Juice against vertiginous Disor∣ders of ye Head, used in form of an Errkine; it is also good for cutaneous Eruptions.
4. Greek, . Latin, Artanta. Cyclamen. Spanish, Pan de Puerco. Italian. Pan Porcino. French, Cyclamen or Pain Porcin. German, Schwenbrot. Dutch, Parkensbrood.

2. It is planted in Gardens, and flowers late in the Summer
3. The Kernels are used by some to purge watery Humors, but they must be ed with great Caution. The Oil expressed from the Seeds is good to destroy in Childrens Heads

2. It flowers in May, and the Fruit is ripe in September.
3. The Flowers & Fruit are both used in the Shops, and are accounted diuretic, good for ye Stone, Gravel, & Pleurisy. The Aqua Nephritica is made of the Flowers.
4. Greek, . Latin. Mespilus, Oxyacanthus. Spanish, Azarolo. Italian, Azarolo. French, Nesplier. German, Dornbaum. Dutch. Doornboom.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 150. Musk Crane's Bill. Geranium moschatum.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow to be a Foot high, the Leaves are a light grass Green, and the Flowers purple.
2. It is generally planted in Gardens, flowring great part of the Summer; some times it is found Wild, in several Parts of England.
3. This is accounted a vulnerary Plant. and is useful in inward Wounds. Bruises and Haemorrhagies. and most Fluxes.
4. Greek, . Latin. Geranium maschatum. Spanish. Pico de Gnguenha. Italian. Geranto rzo. French. Bec de Ccongne. German. Storchschnabel. Dutch.
1. This is a common Hedge. Tree, & seldom grows to any great bigness. the Leaves are a light grass Green, the Flowers white, and the Berries a deep purple.
2. It grows frequently in Hedges near Ditches, and flowers in May the Berries being ripe in September.

3. The Bark. Leaves, Flowers & Berries are used — The inner Bark is much used for the Dropsy — The Leaves outwardly are good for Inflammations. S• anthonys Fire & the Piles, the Flowers are used for the same, and are also put in Fomen¦tations & Cataplasms for all kinds of Swellings. Tumours. & Pairts in the Limbs: inwardly. they expell Wind. & help the Cholic The Berries are cordial & useful in his teru Disorders on the Trunk of this Tree grows an Excressence which they call en Ears, being account∣ed good for ye swelling & Inflammation of the Tonsils, sore Throats and Quinseys.
4. Greek, . Latin. Sambueus Spanish. Cavinero Italian. Sambuco French. Suyer German. Holder Dutch, Derboom
