1. The generally differ according to the Countries they grow in. both in Height and Fruit; this Vine is the Uvae passae majores, or Raisins of the Sun.
2. This Vine is a Native of the warm Countries as Spain. Portugal. Italy and France: it flowers in April and the Grapes are ripe the latter end of Summer.

3. Wine is accounted cordial. strengthens the Snach, helps Digestion. comforts ye Bowels and is a great Preservative against the Plague. — The Raisins of the Sun are made by cutting the Stalks of the Branches, when on the Tree almost in two, by which means they hinder the sap from coming to them in so great a Quantity as it would do other ways, till by the Heat of ye Sun. & Defect of Nourishment they are sufficiently cured
4. Greek. . Latin. Vitis. Vinifera. Spanish. Italian. Vite Vinifera. French. Vigne. German. Weinreb. Dutch,
1. It grows as big as an Apple Tree, the Leaves are a grass Green; the Flowers white, and the Fruit when ripe of a bronmish Green.
2. It is planted in Gardens. flowers in May. and the Fruit is ripe in November.

3. Medlars are esteem'd cooling, drying and binding. (especially before they are quite ripe) and are useful in all Kinds of Fluxes Some commend the Hard Seed as good for ye Gravel and Stone. They are an Ingredient in the Syrupus Mirtinus.
4. Greek. . Latin. Mespilus sava. Spanish, Nesper. Italian. Nespoto. French. Nesplter. German. Nespel Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 155 Kneeholm or Butchers-broom. Bruscus or Ruscus.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow to be a Foot high, the Leaves are a deep Green. the Flowers Yellow with a purple Umbel in the Middle, and the Berries red.
2. It grows in Hedges and Thickets, particularly on Epping Forrest, and flowers for several Months in the Summer

3 The Root is one of the five Opening Roots, and is accounted good for Obstructions of the Liver and Spleen, the Jaundice and Dropsy. It is a strong Diuretic provokes Urine. helps the Gravel and Stone, and brings down the catamenta.
Tournefort commiends a Conserve of the Berties to stop a Gonohea.
4. Greek. . Latin. xymirsine Spanish. Jus barba, and Gal barbera Italian, Brusco & Pongtop. French. Brus. German. Brusch Renssdorn Dutch.

2. It grows upon old Walls, and flowers in. May.

3. The whole. Herb to used being cooling opening and cleansing. containing a nitro Salt, which commends it for the Stone. Gravel Stoppage and Heat for which Ends the Juice or Decoction is given at the Mouth and in Some commend it for Coughs

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 157. The Citrul or Water-melon. Citrullus or Anguria.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks creep on the Ground like the Stalks of a Cucurnber; the Flowers. are yellow and the Fruit Green; and commordy gorws as big as a Pomk in.
2. It is much cultivated in the Warm Countries, as Italy. Spain. Turkey. the East & West Indies; and flowers according to the Months it is sown in.

3. Water Melons are much esteemd for their cooling and refreshing Quality. being very servicedbts in great Heats. The Seed is one of the greater Cold Seeds, and is much of the Nature of Melon and Cucumber, agreeing with them in their cooling ducretis Faculties.

3. Some accouhe the Root a Specifie for the Kings-Evil and scrophulous Swellings, both gwen in wardly and applied outwardly. It is said also to provoke Urine. and to be usefull in Hysteric Disorders.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 165. The Barberry Bush. Berberis, Oxyacantha.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It seldom grows to any great Bigness, the Leaves are a fine grass Green, the Flowers yellow and the Berries red.
2. In some Parts they grow wild, and are also planted in Gardens, flowring in May; the Berries being ripe in September.

3. The Inner Bark of this Bush is accounted a Specific for the yellow Jaundice, either taken in an Infusion or Decoction; being opening and attenuating. The Berries are good to moisten the Houth and quench Thirst in Burning Fevers, being cooling & restringent. The Conserve is serviceable against all kinds of Looseness, Fluxes & ye Jaundice. — The Seed is esteem'd binding & restringent. The officinal Preparation is the Conserve of the Fruit.
4. Greek. Latin, Oxyacantha. Spanish. Italian, Crespino. French. Vinette German, Bersich. Dutch, Berberisse.
1 It ground to be a Foot high, the Leaves are a deep Green & ye Flowers a pale Purple.
2 There are two sorts of this Calamint found in Kent in great Plenty growing by Hedjes. and ring in Iune and Iuly.

3 This Calamint is hotter than common Hint, being a good Stomatic, expelling Wind, and helping the Coll. It is of great Service to the Female Sex, in Obstructions of the catamenia, bringing them to a regular Course; this it does, taken inwardly, or by a strong Decoction given as a ster. The efficinal Preparation is the Pulo Diacal simplex.
4 Greek, . Latin Calamentha, lgaris, montana. Spanish Neveda. Italian, Mpotella montana French, Poullio montagnes, German, Bergmunt, Dutch Calamenth.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 167. The Common Calamint of the Shops Calamentha officinahs.

LIST.ITEM: 1 This Calamint is much like the former, only this lyes much upon the Ground, and the Leaves are smaller the Leaves and Flowers are alike in Colour to the former.
2 It grows in like Places as the former, but flowers in Iuly and August.
3 It has much the same Vertues as the other being opening and dealistruent, and is used often for the other, because it gronis in greater Plenty, and the Shops are mosth Supplied th this.
4 Greek Latin, Calamentha officinalis, or Pulegu odere Nepeta Spanish, Neveda. Italian, Calamenta. French, Poullio sauvage. German, Bilder polen Dutch, Berg Calamenth.

2 It grows on Banks and dry barren Places, flowing in Iune and Iuly.

1. The Stalks grow to be two or three Foot high; the Leaves are a light grass Green, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It grows in Woods and Hedges, flowring in Iuly.

3. The Leaves and Tops are used, this being accounted one of our best vulnerary Plants; and is much used inwardly in traumatic Apozems, and Wound Drinks; and outwardly in Cataplasms and Fomentation. Some recommend it for spitting of Blood and other Haemorrhagies, and think it of great Service in the Stone.
4. Greek Latin, Virga aurea angustifolia minus serrata. Spanish. Italian. Virga aurea. French, La Vierge doree. German, Heydnisch Bunderaut. Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 170. Fluellin or Female Speedwell. Elatine or Veronica foemina.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Plant creeps on the Ground, and has small hairy Stalks about eight Inches long: the Leaves are a dark Green, and the Flowers Purple and yellow.
2. It grows in Corn Fields, and flowers the latter End of Summer.
3. This is a vulnerary Plant, being accounted good for old Illcers and spreading cancer¦ous Sores, Fluxes, Haemorrhagies, and Inflammations of the Eyes.
4. Greek, . Latin, Elatine, Spanish, Italian Elatina. French, German, Fhrenpreiss Beible. Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 171. Motherwortor Marrubuim call'd Cardiaca. Cardiaca.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to be eighteen Inches high; the Leaves are a dark Green on the Face and light on the Back, and the Flowers a red Purple.
2. It grows in Waste Places and Lanes, flowring in Iune.

3 This Plant, from a supposition that it relieves the Disorders of the Heart. as a Palpitation and Swooning, takes the Name of Cardiaca Doctor Bowles has commended a Decoction of it sweetned with Sugar as a singular Remedy for the above Illness, and for Affections of the Spleen and Hysteric Fits. The Powder given in Wine to the Quantity of a Dram is commended as a present Remedy to expediate the Birth.
4. Greek Latin. Marrubuim Cardiaca dutum. Spanish Marojo. Italian. Cardiaca. French Gripaume. German. Herkgesper. Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 173. The Common Service Tree. Sorbus corminalis

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree grows pretty call, the Leaves are a light grass Green, the Flowers a very pale Yellow and the Berries red.
2. It grows in Woods and Thickets, flowring in May: but the Fruit is not ripe till October or November.

3. The Fruit is accounted restringent and binding. good for all kinds of Fluxes. either of Blood or Humors: when ripe it promotes Digestion and prevents the too hasty Passage of the Food into the Bowels; some commend it in Fevers attended with a Diarrhea.
4. Greek, . Latin. Sorbus vulgaris. Spanish. Sorbas Italian. Sorbo salvatico. French. Sorbes sauvage. German. Eheraschen Bogelbeer. Dutch. Wilde Qualster.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 174. The Manur'd Service Tree. Sorbus sativa.

LIST.ITEM: 1 This Tree grows much to the same Height as the former the Flowers the same. the Leaves are a light Green on the Face & some what hoary on ye Back. and the Fruit a redish Brown.
2 It grows wild in Staffordshire and Cornwal. flowring in May. the Fruit being ripe in November.

3. The Fruit when green is very restringent, and useful for all kinds of Flues. This Fruit is seldome to be met with in our Markets, which obliges many to make Use of the former Service Tree in the Place of this.
4. Greek, . Latin Sorbus legittima. Spanish. Sorbas. Italian. Sorba. French. Cormes. German. Sperbiern. Dutch. Tame Qualster.
1. The Bay Tree seldom grows to any great Bigness here, the Leaves are a dark Green above & a pale underweath, ye Flowers are yellowish. and the Barries Black.
2. It grows wild in Spain. Italy and France. flowring in May, the Fruit being ripe in October.

3. The Leaves and Berries are accounted heating, drying, and emollient good for Wind in the Stomach and Bowels. helping ye Collic. comforting ye Head and Nerves preventing Infections, provoking Urine & the Menses. & expelling ye Secundines. Outwardly they are used in Warming and Streng theing Fomentations & Ointment Officinal Preparations are. the Elect. de Baccis Laurt; Emp. de Baccis Lauri. and the Oleum Laurinum.
4. Greek. . Latin. Laurus latisolia mater Spanish. Lauret. Italian. Lauro French. Laurier German. Lorberbaurn. Dutch. Laurierboorn.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 177. Garden Succory. Cichorium sativum or Seris.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to be a Yard high, the Leaves are a grass Green and the Flowers blue.
2. It is planted in Gardens and flowers commonly in Iune and Iuly.

3. Most of the Ancients say that this Plant is cold, but its Bitterness shews it to be hot; and is esteem'd aperative, diuretic, opening Obstructions of the Liver, & helping the Jaundice. It also provokes Urine, and cleanses ye Urinary Parts of slimy Humors. The Officinal Preparation is, the Syrupus de Cichorio cum Rhabarbaw.
4 Greek . Latin, Seris, and Intubus sylvestris. Spanish, Almerones. Italian, Cichoria domestica. French, Cichoree. German, Begweise Begwurk. Dutch, Cichoren.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 178. The Wilding or Crab Tree. Malus sybvestris.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This thee grows smaller than the Garden Apple, the Leaves and Blossomes are much the same in Colour.
2. It grows in Hedges and flowers in April and May.

3. Verjuice is made of the Juice of the Fruit, which is sptic and Binding. good for restringent Gargles, Ulcers in the Mouth and Throat. and falling down of ye Uvula. Outwardly it is good for Burns. Scalds. Inflammations. St Anthony's Fire and red inflammed Eyes.
4. Greek, . Latin. Malus sylvestris. Spanish. Mausawas Italian. Mele salvatico. French. Pomes sauvages German. Bild Depfell. Dutch. Wilde Appelen.
1. It grows two Foot lugh, the Leaves are a blue Green and the Flowers yellow.
2. It grows upon old Walls and flowers in March and April.

3. The Flowers are cordial and cephalic, strengthen the Nerves, help the Apoplexy and Palsy, ease the Green-Sickness, and procure the Menses. The offianal Prepara n is the Oil by Infusion of the Flowers, which is warming. comforting and good for Pains in the Limbs.
4 Greek. Latin. Leucoum luteum vulgare. Spanish. Holetas Italian. Viola galla. French. Violets German. Gelb Regel Beil. Dutch.

2 It grows here in Gardens and flowers in Iune and Iuly

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows about two Foot high, the Leaves are a light Green, and the Flowers sometimes While, and often Red and White.
2. It is planted in Gardens and flowers most Moths in the Summer.

3. Dioscorides commends the Flowers for wcers & Chaps in ye Fundament & Inflam. masions of the Matrix. Galen says. that they help ye Infirmities of ye Liver & Spleen, and provoke th Terms, and has ten the Birth.

3. This Archangel is accounted as great a Specifick for the Excess of ye Catamenia. and all Haeinorrhagies. as the Wlute Archangel is for the Fluor Albus. Some commend is for great Service in Wounds & Inflammations when outivardly applyed.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 185. Field Scabious. Scabiosa wlgaris pratensis.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow to be two or tree Foot high. the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Flowers purple.
2. It grows in Meadows, and flowers in Iune.

3. The Leaves are esteemd cordial alexipharmic. sudorific. pectoral, good for Distempers of the Lungs, as Coughs, shortness of Breath &c; as also sore Throats and Luinsies. Outwardly, they are serwceable in the Itch, scally Sores, Yettars and other cutaneous Distempers. They also take black and blue Marks out of the Skin.
4. Greek . Latin, Scabtosa, Spanish, Italian, Scaiiosa. French. Scabieuse. German, Apostemen Graut. Dutch, Scabiense.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 186. The Scarlet Oak. Ilex coccigera.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This is a small shrubby Oak, with prickly Leaves, on the Twigs of which arow little round Grains, or rather Nests of Insects of a shining reddish Colour about as big as peas, made by small Flies: These Nests are gathered while they are full of little Worms, and being beat in a Mortar, the Scarlet Liquor is straind thro a Steve, and mixt with its equal Weight of Sugar, which is the Succus Kermes of the Shops.
2. It grows in the southern Parts of France. Italy and Turky.
3. The Succus Kermes is accounted cordial. moderatly binding comforng ye Heart, chearing the Animal Spirits, and good to prevent Miscarying. It also drives out the small Pox and Measles.
4. Greek, . Latin glex acculeata cocciglandifera. Sparash, Grana in Grano Italtan. Grana daangere French. Vermillon. German, Scharlachbeer. Dutch. Scharlaaken Besien Boom.

2 It grows upon Heaths, and flowers in May and Iuns; the Berries are green the Vear and ripe the Second.

3 The Wood, Berries and Gum are used: the Wood is accounted hot, dry and cephaltc. good to burn in times of Pesulence & contagtous Distempers. The Berrtes are esteemec arminative, diuretic. expelling Wind. and usesull in the Stone. Gravel & stoppage of Urine. DIV2.HEAD: Plate 189. The Pine Tree, or Manur'd Pine. Pinus, or Pinus sativa.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This is a large Tree, with slender, sharp pointed, dark Green Leaves, yellow Catkins, and brown oblong round pointed Cones.
2. It grows wild in Italy, but is planted here in Gardens, flowring early in the Spring.

3. The Neucle or Kernels are of a balsamic nourishing Nature, and esteem'd good for Consumptions, Coughs and Hoarsness; restorative, and of Service after long Illness. They also help ye Strangury, Heat & sharpness of Urine.
4. Greek, . Latin, Pinus. Spanish, Pino. Italian, Pino. French, Pino. German, Fichtenbaum. Dutch, Pyn Boom.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 190. The Wild Pine. Pinus sylvestris.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Pine grows near as tall as the former, its Leaves are much shorter and slenderer, especially on the Bottom of the Branches, the Catkins & Cones smaller and sharper; but much of the same Colours.
2. It grows in great Plenty in Germany. & flowers much about ye time with the other.

3. From this Tree comes the common Turpentine, chiefly used by the Ferriers; from which is distill'd the oil of Turpentine, and the Spirit; the Dregs that are left at the Bottom of the Still is the common Rosin. Mr. Dale affirms from Doctor Kreg that ye Burgundy Pitch is made of ye Turpentine from this Tree. The Curious may Consult Mr. Miller, the Apothecary's Botanicum officinale p. 347. where there is a beautifull Account of this Tree.
4. Greek, . Latin, Pinus montana. Spanish, Pino de bosque. Italian, Pino salvatico. French, Pin sauvage. German, Bildfichtenbaum. Dutch, Wilde Pynboom.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 191. Orpine or Live-Long. Crassula or Fabaria.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow to be a Foot high, the Leaves are a light blue Green, and the Flowers a pale Purple.
2. It grows in Hedges and shady Places flowring in Iune and Iuly.

3. The Leaves and Flowers are accounted cooling and binding, good for the bloody Flux, tempering the Heat and Acrimony of those Humours which cause an Erosion of the Bowels. Outwardly they are used against Burns and Scalds, and all kinds of Inflammations.
4. Greek, . Latin, Telephium vulgare. Spanish. Italian Favn grassa. French. Reprise or Joubarbe des Vignes. German. Schmerwurkel. Dutch, Smeerwortel.
1. The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a yellow Green, the Flowers white with a yellow Thrum on the Middle.
2. It grows in Hedges and Lanes, flowring in Iune and Iuly.

3. This Plant is particularly appropriated to the Female Sex, being of great Service in all cold flatulent Disorders of the Wmb and hysteric Affections prcuring the Catamenia, and expelling the Birth and Secundines. About two Ounces of the Juice taken an Hour before the Fit is good for all kinds of Agues. It also destroys Worms provokes Urine, and helps the Dropsy and Jaundice.
4. Greek, . Latin Partheruum Spanish Italian. Matricaria French Dutch, eederkruya.

3. The Bark of which they make Cork, is separated from the Tree by making a long Incision from the Head to the Root of the Tree which they take care to do in dry Weather; for the young tender Bark is lyable to be destroyed. and the Trees kill'd by Rain. DIV2.HEAD: Plate 194 The Bay of Alexandria. Laurus Alexandrina.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks are tough & limber, seldom growing to any great Height; the Leaves are a light Green, the Flowers are greenish with a purple Umbo in the Middle.
2. It grows in the Mountainous Parts of Italy, and in Nungary.

3. Dioscordes and Galen recommend it to open Obstructions of the Kidneys & the Womb, to provoke Urine & the Menses; and to help long & hard Labour Some account it a good vulnerary Plant, & useful to dry up old Ulcers and Sores.
4. Greek. . Latin. Laurus Alexandrina genuina. Spanish. Italian, Lauro Aliss and rino. French, Laurer Alexandrin. German. Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 195. The Mastich or Lentisk-Tree. Lentiscus.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree grows to a considerable Bigness in its native Soil; the Leaves are a dark grass Green, the Flowers a greenish Yellow and the Berries black
2. It grows in the Southern Parts of France and in Italy. but it yields the Gum Mastich only in the Island of Scorsor Cos, in the Archipelao.

3. The Gum is esteem'd heating & drying strengthning the Head & Nervous System & Stomach. it eases a Cough, stops spitting of Blood & stays Vomiting. The Ladies in decounted drying & binding good for all kinds of Fluxes.
4. Greek. . Latin Intiscus vulgaris. Spansh. Mata or Arveira. Italian. Lentisco French. Lentisque. German. Hastixbaum. Dutch. Mastix Boom.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 197. The true sweet Gum Cistus of Candy. Cistus landifera vera Creatica.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Shrub grows to be two or three Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green. the Flowers a pale Red with a large purple spot in ye End next the Seed Vessel.
2. It grows in ye Island of Candy. & other places in ye Archipelago & flowers in Iuly.

3. From this Tree comes the Gum Labdanum of ye Shops. which some commend as good for a Looseness & Gripes, caused by sharp Humours. The Fume of it comforts the Brain, & stops catarrhous Defluxions. Outwardly applied, it is accounted strengthening to the Stomach, and stays Vomiting. See Mr Joseph Miller's Botanicum Officinale p. 252. & 253.
4. Greek. . Latin. Cistus Ledan Cretense. Spanish. Cerguacos. Italian, Cisto French, German, Dutch, Lalidanum Boom.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 198. The Common Fir. or Pitch Tree. Abies rubra or Picea.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This grows to be a large Tree, the Leaves are small slender & prickly. of abright grass Green Colour. the Catkins greenish, the Cones a light Brown & ye Seed Brown.
2. It grows wild in Germany & Scotland, sending out its Catkins in the Spring.

3. The Leaves and Tops are used in Dist Drinks for the Scurvy. & are an Ingredient in the Brunswick Mum. The Strasburg Turpentine comes from this Tree, which is mollifying healing & cleansing & a great Diuretic. usefull in Wounds. Ulcers. a Gonorrhea. the Fluor albus, the Stone & Gravel. & Affections of ye Breast & Lungs. Tar is also the Product of this Tree, and is accounted a good pectoral Medicine, useful for shortness of Breath and Obstructions of the Lungs.
4. Greek. . Latin. Picea. Spanish, Pino negro. Italian, Pezzo. French. Posse. Pignet. or Garipolt. German. Rat Zannenbaum. Dutch. Denne Boom.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 199. The Olive Tree. Olea or Olea sativa.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree grows to a great Bigness in its native Climate. the Leaves are a deep Green above & hoary underneath. the Flowers yellow. & the Fruit black when ripe.
2. It grows in Spain. Italy and Turky.

3. The Oil is moderatly healing & mollifying. rendring the Body lax & soluble: it helps Disorders of ye Breast & Lungs. & eases Gripings & the Collic. — It is of great use against all corrosive mineral Poisons. as Arsenic. Sublimate &c. It opens ye Urinary Pasages & is good for ye Stone & Gravel. The pickled Olives are grateful to ye Stomach. and provoke an Appetite. The ripe Olives are a great Part of ye Food of the Easter Countries. among the Greeks; especially in Leno.
4. Greek. . Latin. Olea. Spanish, Olivo or Azeytimo. Italian, Olivo. French, Olivier. German. Delbaum. Dutch. Olyf.

2. It grows in Fields & Meadows onging in March April and May.

3. This is accounted a & rulnerary Plant being used in Wound Drinks. the Leaves are esteem'd good to disolve coneald Blood. Help ye Plour and Perspeumoa Some cominend a Detion given Innardly and a ataplan of ye Leaves applied outwardly as extraordinary Rentedies in the Kings El

1. This is the west India Tamarind; the specimen of the Tree is taken from one in the Stove in ye Physick Garden, and the Fruit is taken from the Life out of Mr. Rand's collection. This Tree grows very large in the West Indies; the Leaves are a light grass Green, the Flowers white & yellow with purple Veins; the Pods a brownish yellow tinctured with Red; the Pulp of the Pos is yellow at first & then changes into a brownish black; & the Stones are a reddish shining Brown.
2. It grows in the West Indies, and flowers in Summer.
3. These Tamarinds are generally eat by themselves, without any other Medicine mixe with them; and are accounterd good to purge choleric Humours, & correct the bilous Heat in the Stomach and Bowels.
4. Greek, . Latin, Tamarindus. Spanish. Italian French, German Dutch, Tamarinde.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 202. The Palm or Date Tree, Dactilus or Palma.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This is a large Tree with a rough scaly Bark on the main Stem the Leaves grow on the Top of the Tree in form of the sticks of a Fan; the Flowers are white, and the Fruit yellow and red.
2. It grows in Barbary, Egypt and Syria.
3. The Dates are much used for Food in the Countries where they grow; here they are esteem'd drying and binding, usefull for Fluxes, and to smooth the Roughness of the Aspera Arteria.
4. Greek Latin, Palma, Spanish, Palmera. Italian, Palma. French, Palmier german, Datte Uaum. Dutch, Dadel.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 203 The male Fir, or silver Fir. Abies mas.

LIST.ITEM: 1 This grows to be very large, the Leaves are broad at the Ends & white underneath: and the Cones grow exect.
2 This Tree is said to grow wild in some Parts of England, but is found in great Pienty in the mountainous Parts of Germany.

3 This is the Tree which ought to be used in the shops according to the Dispensatory but not being so common as the Spruce, that generally supplies its Place, the Vertues of both being much the same. See the Explanation of Plate 198.
4 Greek Latin, Uies mas, Corus sursum spectantibus. Spanish, Ueto. Italian, Unet German, Dannenbaum. Dutch, Denne Boom.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 206. The Magellanic Bay like Tree or Winter's Bark, Cortex Winteranus.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Bark of this Tree, which is ye Part chiefly used, is a brownish Ash colour, the Leaves a blue Green, & the Flowers purple succeeded by Green Berries.
2. It grows on the Magellanic Coasts.

3. This Bark is rarely to be met with in the Shops; it is accounted a specific against the Scurey, and a good Nervine Medicine, helpfull in Palsies and Convulsions; some account it good for Diseases of the Stomach and Borvels.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 209. The Carob Tree. Carobe or Siliqua.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree grows to a considerable Bigness in its native Climate, the Leaves are a bright grass Green, the Flowers red, the Pods a bronwish red, and the Fruit a deep red.
2. IT gorws in Syria & Greet. & flowers in ye Spring, the Fruit being ripe in Autumn.

3. Matthiolus recommends the Fruit as good for the Stomach, and Griping of ye Guts, & to provoke Urine. The Decoction of the Beans is accounted by nim a great Cure for an irweterate Cough, and the Tissicl.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 210. The Tree of Life. Arbor Vitae.

2 Its native Climata is Canada.
3. The Leaves are accounted digesting and atteruating. parkinson says they have done great Service in freeing the Lungs from thick Flegm, by chewing them fasting in the Morning.
4. Greek . Latin. Lycia Cedrus. Spanish. Italian. Cedro Lycio. French. German. Dutch.
1. It grows about half a Foot high; the Leaves are a dark Green and the Flowers a pale Purple.
2. It grows wild in Spain. and flowers here in Iuly.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 213. The Wild Olive Tree. Olea sylves is or Oleaster.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree grows less than the manur'd Olive, the Leaves are a gruss Green. the Flowers white with a blush of purple in them, & the Fruit black when ripe.
2. It gorws in great Plenty in Tuscany and flowers in April.

3. Matthiolus recommends the Leaves & the Wood as binding & cooling. Dioscorides says the oil is exceeding as tringent; and accounts the Leaves adn Fruit good for Se Arthony's Fire and corroding Sores.
4. Greek, . Latin, Oleaster, Spanish. Zebuche. Italia, Olivo salvatico. French, Chiver sauvage. German Bilder olbaum. Dutch. Wilde olyf
1. It seldome grows call in England; the Leaves are a grass Green the FLowers Green and the Berries a blackish purple.
2. It is planted here in Gardens. and seldome produces Fruit for which some have thought it barren.

3. Savine is accounted hot & dry, opening & attenuating, being a great provoker of the Catamenia. causion Abortion & expelling the Birth. It is is teemd good to destroy Worms in Children. for which Purpose Mr Ray commends the Juice mixt with Mile & sweetned with Sugar; the Juice beat into a Cataplasm with Hogs Lard, cures Childrens Scabby Heads. Officinal Preparations are the Ol. Sabinae per Insusionem. et decoctionem. & the Oleum Sab. chymicum.
4. Greek, . Latin. Sabina. Spanish, Sabina. Italian, Savina. French, Savirtier German, Sebenbaum. Dutch, Sevenbom.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 215. Wall-fern or Poly pody of the Oak. Polypodium Quercinum

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Plant grows about eight of ten Inches high, on the back of the Leaves grow the Flowers of a reddish brown Colour.
2. It gorws on old Walls adn Trees, and flowers in Autumn.

3. The Roots are esteemd opening. & good to purge biliose Humours. & open Obsuc of ye Liver, help the Jaundice & Dropfy & prowke Urine. Some account them good for the Scurw for uch, they are frequently an Ingredient in Antiscor butic Diec Drinks
4. Greek. Latin. Filicula, Spanish, Polipopio Itulian. Polipodto French. Podypode German. Dropffwurk. Dutch. Booen

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 216. Spleen Wor Ceterach. Milovast. Asplemum. seterach. Scelopendria.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows about four In thes high, the Leaves are a dark Green on the upper Side & blownish on the back Side which is orcasiened by the Seeds growing there
2. It grows on Old Walls and Bildings

3. This is one of the five Capillary Plants, mking us. same from the good Effects it has in curing the Diseases of the Spleen. taking away the Swellings, and hindering its two great Largriess. whence it is called. is also opens Olftrenons of the Lver. and helps the Jaundi and is good to cure the Rickets in Children

1. The stalks that bear the Seed grow to be 7 or 8 Inches high, & those that bear the Leaves are about 8 Foot high; the Leaves are a bright Green & flowers brown.
2. It grows in Ditches and marshy Grounds, flowring in March.

3. Horsetail is accounted restringent drying & binding, good to stop Bleeding in Wounds, and all Haemorrhagies in any part of the Body, the catamenia and Fluor albus, Ulcerations in ye Kidneys or Bladder; & is useful in all kinds of Ruptures.
4. Greek, . Latin, Equisetum. Spanish, Goda de Mula. Italian, Coda di Cavallo. French, Queve de Cheval. German, Rosschwants Dutch, Paardestaart.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 218. Sea Scurvy-Grass. Cochlearia Britannica Marina.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows to be 8 Inches high, the Leaves are a light Green & the Flowers white.
2. This Scurvy Grass grows in great plenty by the Thames Side below Woolwich and flowers in March and April.

3. This Plant is frequently used in Scorbutic Remedies along with the Garden Scurvy-Grass; but wanting its fine volatile Parts, it seems not to prevalent; but abounding more in Saline it may be used to good Purpose as a Diuretic.
4. Greek, Latin, Cochlearia Britannica. Spanish, Italian. French, Herbe aux Cuiliers. German, Dutch, Lepelbladen.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 219. White Maiden Hair. Adianthum Album.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow about 3 or 4 Inches high, the Leaves are a light Green above, and brown underneath by reason of the Seed.
2. It grows on old Stone Walls & Buidings.

3. This is one of the five Capillary Herbs mentioned in the Dispensatory, & has the same Virtues with the rest of the Maiden Hairs, being opening & attenuating and good for Distempers of the Lungs and Breast; and is useful in pectoral Decoctions and Diuretic Apozems.
4. Greek, . Latin, Ruta muraria, or Salvia Vitue. Spanish, Culantrillo depozzo blanco. Italian, Capel Venere bmco. French, Capil Venere blanque. German, Frawen Har. Dutch, Steenruyte.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 220. Black Maiden Hair. Adianthum Nigrum.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Maiden Hair grows about a Span high, the Leaves are a bright Green above, and underneath they are covered with small Brown Seed
2. It grows in Shady Lanes and at the Roots of Trees.

3. This is also one of the five Capillary Herbs; & the Virtues are much the same as ye common Maden Hair, being useful for Coughs & all affections of ye Lungs and Diseases of ye Kidneys. Some commend it as good for the Jaundice.
4. Greek, . Latin, anthum nigrum vulgare or Onepeteris syemina Spanish, Culantrllo depozz negro Italian, Capel nere French, capal venere n German, Franen Ha Dutch, Drunn Hairkruyd.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 221. The East India Tamarinal. Tamarindus Indica Orientalis.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree differs from the West India Tamarind in the Leaves & Fruit; & is better to be used in Medicines than the other because the Fruit contains more Pulp.
2. It grows in the East Indies and flowers in the Spring, this Specimen of the Tree and fruit is taken from the Malabar Garden.

3. Tamarinds are accounted cooling and opening, good to purge choleric Humors, and correct the bilious Heat of the Stomach and Bowels; they also are good to allay Thirst, promote Urine, and help the Jaundice.
4. Greek, . Latin, Tamarindi. Spanish. Italian. French. German. Dutch.
1. The Stalks grow about a Span high, the Leaves are a bright Green above and whitish underneath, and the Flowers purplish.
2. It grows in Marshy Grounds, and on Banks by River Sides; & flowers the Begining of March.

3. The Roots are esteemed sudorific, and alexip harmic, good for all Kinds of Fevers and malignant Distempers; preventing Fainting and shortness of Breath, provoking Urine and destroying joint Worms. Outwardly they are used as a Cataplasm for pestilential Buboes and Plague Sores. A good Quantity of them is put into the Aq. Theriacalis.
4. Greek, . Latin, Petasites major. Spanish, Italian, Farfara maggiore. French, German, Pestilenswurt. Dutch.
1. The Stalks grow about a Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green and the Flowers a pale purple, and often white.
2. It grows in Meadows and on Banks, flowring in March and April.
3. It is accounted heating and warming, good for the Scurvy, the Stone and Gravel, Dropsy and jaundice.
4. Greek, . Latin Nasturtium pratense magno flore. Spanish Berros. Italian Cressone minore. French Cresson de l'Eau. German, Wasser Cressen. Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 225. Ground Ivy or Alehoof. Hedera terrestris.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow about eight Inches long, the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Flowers blue.
2. It grows by Hedges and Banks, flowring in April.

3. This Plant is esteem'd a very goodPectoral being much used for Coughs, Shortness of Breath and other Disorders of the Lungs: for which a Tea made of the Leaves & a Syrup of the Juice is very beneficial. It is this Plant that they make the Gill Me with, being accounted antiscorbutic and appreative, and good to provoke Urine & cleanse ye Ureters. Some Authors commend it steeped in Brandy as of Great Service against the Collic. The Officinal Preparation is, the syrup of ye Juice.
4. Greek, . Latin, Chamaecissus. Spanish, Eda. Italian, Hedera terrestris. French, Lierre de la Terre. German Gundelreben, Dutch, Hondsdraf.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 226. The Cowslip or Paigle. Paralysis.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalk grow about six Inches high, the Leaves are a grass Green above and whitish underneath, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It grows in moist Meadows and Marshes, flowring in April.

3. The Flowers are accounted cordial, and beneficial to the nervous Sistem, good against the Epilepsy. Palsy. Apoplexy & Pains in ye Head; Some say they are andoyne & good to procure sleep for which Purpose they make Tea of them. The Leaves are used in warming, strengthening Ointments, particularly the Unguent Nervinum Officinal Preparations are The simple Water, The Syrup and the Conserve.
4. Greek. Latin Primula veris major. Spanish, Italian, Fiore de Primavera. French Primavere German, Schlusselblumen. Dutch, Sleutelblom.
1. The Stalks grow to be eight or nine Inches high, the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Flowers white.
2. It grows wild in the North of England by the Sea Side, but is very much cultivated in Gardens, and flowers in April.

3. This Plant abounds with fine wlatile Parts, and therefore ye Herb infused or the Juice express'd is more prevalent than a Decoction, the volatile Parts flying away in the Boiling, and is accounted a Specific Remedy against the Scurvy Cleansing and purifying the Juices of the Body from the bad Effects of that Distemper, and clearing the Skin from Scabs Pimples & foul Eruptions Officinal Preparations are. The Simple Water, The Spirit, and a Conserve.

3. Dioscorides commends the Root as good to provoke Urine and bring down the Menses; and an Ointment made from the Ashes of the Root he says procures the Hair to grow when it has fallen off thro any Distemper.
4. Greek. . Latin. Asphodelus foemina or luteus. Spanish. Gamonites. Italian, Anfodillo. French, Asfodele. German. Gelb Affodellwurk. Dutch.
1. The Stalks grow near a Foot high. the Leaves are a light gra2s Green. and the Flowers a light Blue.
2. It grows by Hedges and amongst Corn. flowring in April and May.
3. Bugloss is much of the Nature of Borrage being accounted cordial and good to exhilarate the Spirits, & drive away Melancholy, & is of Service in hypocondriac and hysteric Disorders.
4. Greek, . Latin. Buglossum sylvestre-minus. Spanish Borrajenes. Italian. Buylossa salvatica. French Buglose sauvage. German. Ochsenzung. Dutch. Buglosse or Osse tongep.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 235. Red Beet. Beta rubra, or nigra.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow about two Foot high. te Leaves area dark Green, tinctured with Purple. and the Flowers small and Staminous.
2. It is planted in Gardens and flowers in April and May.

3. Beets are esteem'd good to loosen the Belly. and temperate hot choleric Humors. THe Juice of ye Roots is sometimes used as an Errhine being snuffed up ye Nose to clear the Head of Flegm and mucous Humors, and by that means to help old Head Achs.
4. Greek, . Latin, Be rubra vulgaris. Spanish. Aselgas. Italian. Bietola rossa. French, Poiree rouge German. Rot Ruben. Dutch. Roode Beete
1. The Stalks grow about a Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green and the Flowers white
2. It is sown in Gardens. flowring in April and May
3. This Plant has much of the nature of Parsley. being aperitive & atteruting and ogod for the Stone and Gravel. and to provoke Urine and the Menses
4. Greek. . Latin. Chaerophyllum sativum Spanish. Italian. Cerofogo French. German. Gerbelorant. Dutch. Kervel

1. The Stalks grow about eight Inches high, the Leaves are a light Green, and the Flowers Purple.
2. It grows in Fields and till'd Grounds. flowring in May.

3. This Plant is accounted a great Cleanser of the Blood being good for all Sorts of Cutaneous Distempers & leprous Disorders. It is much drank with Whey in the Spring to purge & purify ye Blood & help ye Scurvy. Iaundice & Affections of the Spleen.
4. Greek. . Latin. Fumaria officinarum et Dioscoridis. Spanish. Palomelha. Italian. Furnosterno. French. Fumeterre. German. Erderauch Rakentorbel. Dutch. Duyderkerdel.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 238. The tue white Asphodel. Asphodelus verus, albus

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow about three Foot high, the Leaves are a light grass Green. and the Flowers white with purple Veins.
2. It is a native of Spain, Italy and the Southern Parts of France: and is planted here in Gardens flowring in April.

3. Dioscorides commends the Root as good for eating Ulcers. In flammations in the Breast or Blotches in the Skin. The Juice of the Root he says cures Scabby Ears. and eases the Pain of the Teeth by pouring some of it into ye contrary Ear where the Tooth aches. Ne also recommends ye Root to provoke Urine & bring down the Menses.
4. Greek, . Latin. Asphodelus albus ramosus mas. Spanish. Gamones. Italian. Anfodillo. French. As fo dele. German. Affodillwurt. Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 239. Great Woolf's-bane or Leopard's-bane. Doronicum Romanorum.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The stalks grow about eighteen Inches high; the Leaves are a dull Green. and the Flowers yellow.
2. It is a native of the Alps. and is planted here in Gardens flowring in April.

3. Some commend the Root against the Poison of Scorpionis; others acount it a Poison. and say it will destroy Woolves, Dogs. & other Animals. Those who have a mind to see ye Arguments on both Sides. may consult Lebel & Matthiolus.
4. Greek. Latin. Doronicum radice Scorpii Spanish. Italian Doronico. French. Le Doronic. German. Gemsenwurt Dutch. Dororucum.
1. This grows to be a call. Tree. the Leaves are a bright grass Green. and the Catkins brownish.
2. It grows in Woods. and the Catkins come out in April.

3. The Liquor that comes from this Tree bored in the Spring is accounted good for the Stone. Gravel. Strangury & bloody Urine. The Leaves are esteemd good for the Dropsy & Itch. used both inwardly & outwardly The Wood neat to Juniper is preferd to burn in times of Pestilence & contgious Distempers
4. Greek. Latin. Betula Spanish. Italian. Bettola French. Le Bouleau. German Biten Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 241 Stechas, or French Lavender. Stoechas at abica or purpurea.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Shrub grows about three Foot high. the Leaves are a whitish Green and the Flowers a deep purple.
2. IT grows naturally in Spain. and the Southern. parts of France. and is planted here in Gardens, flowring in April and may.

3. The Flowers are acconted cordial & cephalic. Strcng thening the Genus Nervofum and are use full in Apoplexies. Palsies & Conwulsions. They are also opening & attenuating. promoting the Catamenia and resisting Poisons
4. Greek, . Latin. Stoechas arabica or Steochas purpurea. Spanish Tomani or Cantuello Italian, Stechade. French Stechados. German, Stichascraut Dutch Sconechas.
1 The Stalks grow about three Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Flowers white with purple Veins
2. It is sown in Gardens. and flowers in April and May.

3 The Leaves are often eat as a Sallad with other Herbs, Some acount it a Stimulus to Fenery. & a good Diuretie Matthiolus comends the Syrup of the Leaves as goof for Childrens Coughs. Cammerarius that an equal part of Rocket and cummin Seed powdred is a good preservalive against the Apoplexy.
4. Greek . Latin. Eruca latifolia alba. Spanish. Oruga. Italian. Rucola. French. Roquete German. Beiss Senff. Dutch. Rakette.
1 The Stalks grow about four Eoot high, the Leaves are a bright grass Green. and the Flowers white
2 It is sown in Gardens. and flowers in April and May.

3 This Plant is often eat as a Sallad, being much of the same Nature as Chervil. conststina of hot & than Parts. being good for cold windy Stomachs. opening Obstritc. tions of the Liver and Spleen. & provoking Urine.
4 Greek, . Latin. Myrrhis major. & Cicutaria ederata Spanish. Italian. Mtrrade French. German. Belscher Gorbel. Dutch.
1 The Stalks grow about Eight or ten Foot high, the Leaves are a dark Green. and the Flowers a toht Vellen.
2 It growa in Fields and on Commens, flowring in May.

3 The Stalks Flowers & Seed are used & are to proveke the & open of the lres & Spleen It is esteemd good for ye Drepty in sused in common Drthk to ye sspan in Nine some psskle ye Flowers better then are full with Salt and use them instead of Capers them good of the Spleen
4 Greek anoulesa et Sopar Spantsh, Genestra Ginestra French. German. Ginst Dutch Brem.

1. The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a dark grass Green with reddish Veins, and the Flowers red.
2. It is planted in Gardens and flowers in April and May.

3. The Flowers Seed & Roots are esteem'd cephalic. & good for the Epilepsy. Apoplexy. & all kinds of Convulsions; both in young & old-They are also accounted good in histeric Cases, Obstructions of the Menses and the Retention of the Lachia. The Root and Seed are hung about Children's Necks to prevent Convulsions in Breeding dieir Teeth.
4. Greek, . or . Latin, Paeonia folio nigricante splendido que Mas. Spanish. Roia del Monte. Italian, peonia. French, Pivovne or Pynoine. German, Peonien. Dutch, Pioene maneke
1. The Stalks grow about three or four Foot high, the Leaves are a willon Green, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It gorws wild in several Parts of England, but is generally Sown for the use of the Dyers: and flowers in May.

3. Woad is esteemd restringent & drying. and is good to stop inward & outward Bleedings. Some commend it much for Ruptures & Strains, and to Strengthen the Joints-It is an Ingredient in the Emplastrum ad herniam.
4. Greek. . Latin, Glastum & Jsatis sativa, or latifolia. Spanish, Pastel. Itlian, Guado. French, Gueda or Pastel. German. Weid. Dutch.
1. This grows to be a large Tree. the Leaves are a yellow Green. & ye Catkins yellowish
2. It is planted in Walks. parks & and the Catkins come out in-April.

3. The Bark is accounted a strong Emetic. either Green, or drued and powdered The Green Nuts are cordial & alexipharmis being of great use in all contagious maliagnant Distempers. & even the plague; they are one of the Principal Ingredient in the Treacle Water The Nuts preserved are good to be eat in a Mornina to prevent Infection in the time of pestilential Distempers. The or three Ounces of the expressd from the ripe Kernels. is a very good medicine for the Stone and Gravel. The Shells powdered or burnt are accounted restringent.
4. Greek . Latin Nur juglans or regia loar is Spanish. Nceses. Italian. Beet French. German. Welsehnuss Dutch. Ockernooten.

2 It grows by Natery Places and the Catkins come out in

1. The Stalks grow two or three Foot high, the Leaves are a blue Green, and the Flowers red.
2. It grows by Hedges and the Sides of Roads flowring in May & Iune.

3. The Root is accounted cold drying, & binding, good for Catarhous Defluxions upon the Lungs; and all kinds of Fluxes & Haemorrhagies, & a Gonorrhed. Some account it a vulnerary, & use it for scrophulous Tumors, taken inwardly, or applied outwardly as a Cataplasm. The Officinal Preparation is ye Pilul Cynogloss.
4. Greek, . Latin, Cynoglossa, & Cynoglossum majus vulgare. Spanish, Italian, Lengua Canina. French, Langue de Chien. German, Hundstung. Dutch, Honds tonge.
1. The Stalks grow three Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green and the Flowers white.
2. It is a Native of Italy, and is planted here in Gardens flowring in May.

3. The Root is esteem'd alexipharmic, sudorific & Cephalic, being of great Service in malignant Fevers & pestilential Distempers. It also helps the Head & Nerves, provokes Urine and brings down the Menses. It is an Ingre¦dient in the Theriaca and Mithridate.
4. Greek, . Latin, Valeriana hortensis & Phu folio Olusatri Dioscoridis. Spanish, Yerva beneditta. Italian, Valeriana. French, Valerienne. German, Valdrian. Dutch, Hof Valeriana
1. The Stalks grow two Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green above and a willow Green underneath, and the Flowers white tinctured with Green.
2. It grows wild in several Woods & Copses here and flowers in May.

3. The Leaves & Root are used, being esteem'd vulnerary and restringent, good to stop all Kinds of Fluxes & Haemorhagies, & consolidate Wounds. Fractures & Ruptures, especially the Root. Matthiolus commends the Root, preserved in Sugar, as of great Service against ye Fluor albus. Some say a Cataplasm of ye Root is good to take away black & blue Marks arising from Contusions.
4. Greek, . Latin, Polygonatum latifolium vulgare. Spanish, Italian, Ginochaetto. French, Genicuere. German, Weiss urt. Dutch. Salomons Seyel.
1. The Stalks grow Foot high, the Leaves are a dull grass Green & ye Flowers white
2. It grows on Banks by River Sides & Watery Places, flowring in May & Iune.

3. The Root Leaves & Flowers are used being accounted vulnerary, whence it takes the ame of Consolida. It is esteemed good for inward Bruises spitting of Blood and sharp orrding Humours that cause Erosions in the Bowels Some com¦mend the Roots beat to a Cataplasm as good for the Gout.
The Officinal Preparation is the Syrup de Symphyto.
4. Greek, . Latin, Consolida major Spanish Consuelda major Italian. Consolida matere. French, Cree de German, Schartwust. Dutch, Smeerwertel.
